DOC.HEAD: Contras Kept in Hotels, No Evidence of Massacre Found
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with investigation finding no proof of Contra claims of massacre, government comment on Contra detention, CORRECTS spelling of Sovalbarro. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Police units Saturday prevented Contra rebel leaders from leaving two hotels where they came to negotiate their disarmament with the government. One Contra leader said they were being held ``hostage.'' Later in the day, members of a government investigative team announced they found no proof of Contra claims that the army massacred 14 rebels who had laid down their weapons. Contra leaders broke off the disarmament talks with the government on Friday demanding an investigation of the purported army massacre of the rebel fighters and 100 civilians May 18 near Waslala in Matagalpa province, 150 miles northeast of Managua. Contra commander Oscar Sovalbarro was named to the commission created Friday, but he remained in Managua on Saturday in a hotel where he said he and 18 other Contras were being held ``hostage'' by police. Sovalbarro said 10 other Contra leaders were prevented from leaving another Managua hotel. He said the rebels were considering a hunger strike in protest. The police who surrounded the Managua hotels did not appear to be threatening the rebels, but Contra leaders said they were told they could not leave the hotel grounds. Presidential spokesman Danilo Lacayo and Interior Minister Carlos Hurtado told The Associated Press that police had been placed at the hotel for the Contras' own protection. The leftist Sandinistas, who turned over power to President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro last month after losing February elections, still control the military and police. Sovalbarro, also known as Commander Ruben, said Saturday's police action showed the Contras ``have a good reason not to trust the government.'' He spoke from the garden of the Hotel Mercedes, where about two dozen police from the elite black beret unit were seen patrolling. The investigative commission, named by Mrs. Chamorro, traveled Saturday by helicopter to the area of the purported massacre and interviewed army and rebel leaders, said Santiago Murray, representative of the U.N. International Support and Verification Commission, at a news conference later in the day. ``We haven't been able to confirm the existence of any dead alleged by the Nicaraguan Resistance,'' he said. He said the commission members found no information about ``any dead or other serious incident.'' People interviewed near Waslala in the community of Zinica, where rebels alleged the incident occurred, seemed surprised by news of a massacre and said they had heard about it from a Managua radio station. The investigating commission consisted of government delegates, U.N. officials, Roman Catholic Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo and a Contra representative. A May 4 agreement between the Contras and the Chamorro government set a June 10 deadline for more than 11,000 rebels to surrender their weapons. But on May 19, the Contra high command suspended the disarmament, claiming authorities were not providing enough food, housing, jobs and security measures for fighters who lay down their arms. Only 1,404 of the rebel fighters have been demobilized, the government said. The U.S.-backed Contras fought the Sandinista government in a 10-year war that left 30,000 dead. The rebel fighters said they would give up their arms after Mrs. Chamorro, also backed by the United States, took over the presidency from Sandinista President Daniel Ortega on April 25. The Contras say their chief concern is that the army is controlled mostly by Sandinistas.

DOC.HEAD: Wet Over Much Of Eastern Two-Thirds Of Nation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to UPDATE with Oklahoma tornadoes; INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf, `Hail fell ...' to ADD detail. Pick up 4th graf, `Showers and ...'
DOC.TEXT: Storms stretched over broad sections of the nation's midsection Saturday, producing at least three tornadoes in Oklahoma and extending from the Ohio Valley to the East Coast and New England. At midday, showers and thunderstorms extended over southeastern Kansas, southwestern and south-central Missouri, northern Arkansas, northeastern and south-central Oklahoma, northeastern Colorado, southwestern and north-central Nebraska, north-central and central Texas, northwestern and southeastern North Dakota and central Minnesota. Hail fell in parts of Oklahoma, with stones as big as golf balls at Bartlesville, the National Weather Service said. Hail almost an inch in diameter near Fayetteville, Ark. Five homes in Caddo County, Okla., were destroyed by one of at least three funnel clouds that moved through central Oklahoma on Saturday night, officials said. Showers and thunderstorms also covered southern Florida. Rain and showers extended from southern and central Indiana to southern and central Ohio, northeastern Kentucky, northern West Virginia, eastern Virginia, Delaware, Maryland, southern and eastern Pennsylvania, New Jersey, southeastern New York state and southern New England. Rain also fell over northwestern Montana, northern Nevada, northern California and the northern coast of Washington state. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 2.5 inches at Chanute, Kan.; 1.89 inches at Parkersburg, W.Va.; and 1.52 inches at Elkins, W.Va. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 47 degrees at Yellowstone National Park, Wyo., to 99 degrees at Sanderson, Texas. Saturday's low for the Lower 48 states was 26 degrees at Butte, Mont.
Midnight EDT: 109.

DOC.HEAD: Burma Holds First Multiparty Election in 30 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 21 grafs to UPDATE with scene at polling places, comments by head of military council and opposition official, CLARIFIES that first returns expected by Monday morning. Pickup 13th graf pvs: Pro-democracy parties ...
DOC.TEXT: Burmese voted Sunday in the country's first multiparty election in 30 years, but the military regime has kept some opponents out of the campaign and other groups were boycotting the balloting. Pro-democracy forces hope the elections for a national assembly will pave the way for an end to military rule. But some analysts question whether the military intends to yield any real power to liberal forces. In Rangoon, the capital, thousands of Burmese lined up outside schools and government buildings before the polls opened at 6 a.m. There were no immediate reports of any disturbances, and troops kept largely out of sight. Gen. Saw Maung, the head of the ruling military council, said he was ready to step aside for a civilian government. ``I have already abided by my promise and am going back to the barracks,'' Maung told reporters after casting his ballot in downtown Rangoon. ``I will transfer power according to the law.'' He said the timetable for a transfer to civilian rule would depend on the political parties in the national assembly. The military has promised to step down from power when the parliament puts together a new constitution, a process that could take several years. An official at the headquarters of the National League for Democracy, the main opposition group, said the voting appeared to be proceeding well. ``The election is going smoothly right now,'' said the official, who requested anonymity, in a telephone interview. ``There is no problem right now.'' The country's three most popular opposition leaders were barred from a role in the campaign, and Western diplomats, human rights groups and others have expressed concern over widespread arrests, intimidation of party workers and martial law restrictions. A welter of ethnic minority groups and student dissidents are boycotting the election. But on Saturday, rebel sources in Bangkok, Thailand, said they had called off earlier plans to sabotage polling, even though they regard the election as fraudulent. The ruling military council has pledged that voting will be fair and free. In recent days, it eased restrictions on campaigning. Two years ago, huge street demonstrations in Rangoon were brutally crushed by military force. In public, there were few of the trappings of a Western-style election campaign. Political posters were banned except at party headquarters. Government signs urged people to obey the law to ensure a fair election. The Rangoon government closed off the country to tourists and rejected requests from several human rights and legal organizations to monitor the election. However, last week it granted visas to about 60 journalists from the United States, Western Europe and elsewhere in Asia. Journalists were told their coverage would not be restricted, except for a ban on entering polling stations. Results from Rangoon are expected to be released by Monday morning. But a final tally will not be available for up to three weeks due to difficulties in obtaining results from remote, rural areas. Predictions about the outcome range from a substantial victory for the democratic parties to a fractured vote that could lead to continued military domination. Pro-democracy parties hope to return to a liberal multiparty government, abolished by the military in 1962. The conservative National Unity Party stands for the status quo. Parties have been vague on specific political and economic issues. Criticism of the military was forbidden during campaigning and discussion of other topics was restricted as well. About 21 million people are eligible to vote in the elections, choosing 492 parliamentarians from among 2,297 candidates. Voting has been postponed in seven constituencies due to security and communications problems. Burma's three best-known opposition figures were sidelined during the campaign. Aung San Suu Kyi, daughter of independence hero Aung San, was placed under house arrest last July. Retired Gen. Tin Oo is serving a three-year jail term. Former Prime Minister Nu, who presided over chaotic experiment in democracy during the 1950s, is under house arrest. Ms. Suu Kyi and Tin Oo headed the National League for Democracy, the country's most popular party. It faces off against the conservative National Unity Party, successor to the pro-military Burma Socialist Program Party which wielded power for a quarter century. Although 93 parties have entered the contest, only some half dozen are expected to make any substantial showing. These include the League for Democracy and Peace, backed by Nu; the Union Nationals Democracy Party of Aung Gyi; Thu Wai's Democracy Party, and the Democratic Front for National Reconstruction headed by onetime leftist leader Chit Maung. The National Unity Party has an efficient and well-financed machine but is handicapped by the ruinous record of its predecessor and popular resentment of the military following the bloody events of 1988. The National League for Democracy has been weakened by internal feuding, the loss of its top leadership and arrests of its supporters and candidates. Suu Kyi's downfall came when she publicly criticized Ne Win, Burma's strongman between 1962 and 1988. Burma, a nation of 41 million, has suffered from political turmoil and civil war since its independence from Great Britain in 1948, when many regarded it as a future Asian dynamo. A period of flawed democracy, but relative economic prosperity, was followed by a 1962 coup led by Ne Win and a failed experiment in mixing military control, socialist economics and international isolationism. The resource-rich country is now among the world's poorest. A major drain on the economy has been a decades-long war between the central government and a dozen ethnic minority groups demanding greater autonomy.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia's Flight Devoted Solely To Science
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with countdown started. Pick up 4th graf, `Columbia's payload ...'
DOC.TEXT: Columbia will be making the first shuttle flight in five years devoted entirely to scientific research when it lifts off this week on a mission to study the stars, a comet and other celestial matter. Launch is set for 12:38 a.m. EDT Wednesday, two weeks later than planned because NASA had to replace a bad cooling valve in Columbia's payload bay. ``It looks very good. There have been ups and downs a lot, so everybody's very excited about the prospects of getting this mission off,'' mission manager Jack Jones said Friday. The countdown for launch began on schedule at 1 a.m. Sunday, a NASA spokesman said. Columbia's payload, a $150 million observatory called Astro, will provide a much more thorough study of ultraviolet light than the Hubble Space Telescope, placed in orbit a month ago during the last shuttle flight. Astro also will probe X-rays, invisible to Hubble. ``We selected Astro to fill in the holes, so to speak,'' explained Ed Weiler, a program scientist for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. It will be the first mission since 1985 to use Spacelab, a scientific research facility carried in the shuttle's payload bay. It also will be the first of five Spacelab missions dedicated to a single subject _ astrophysics. The four astronomers on board will operate Astro from the rear flight deck using Spacelab computers; a pressurized laboratory module in which astronauts conduct experiments will not be used. Other Spacelab components will support the 27,450-pound observatory in the open payload bay. It will be the first of 36 shuttle missions to offer ``Lessons from Space.'' More than 40 middle-school students at two NASA centers will question the astronauts through a two-way audio and video link. And it will be the first time direct radio communication is made between a U.S. and Soviet spacecraft. Columbia's astronauts plan to talk by ham radio to two cosmonauts aboard the Soviet space station Mir. During the nine- to 10-day mission 218 miles above Earth, Astro's four telescopes will make nearly 1,000 observations of up to 230 sources of ultraviolet and X-ray radiation, short, high-energy wavelengths absorbed by the atmosphere. At least four observations are planned of Comet Austin, making what's believed to be its first journey through the solar system. Halley's Comet would have been studied if Astro had gone up as planned in March 1986; the Challenger accident two months earlier postponed the mission. Astronaut Samuel Durrance, a research scientist at Johns Hopkins University, said it's hard to predict what Astro might uncover on its first outing. But, he added, ``every time we point the telescopes, it could change the way astronomers think.'' Unlike Hubble, a $1.5 billion observatory astronomers hope will explain how and when the universe was created, Astro won't be focusing on any ``mind-boggling question,'' said astronaut Ronald Parise, a scientist at Computer Sciences Corp. in Silver Spring, Md. The Hopkins Ultraviolet Telescope, developed by Johns Hopkins University, will examine ultraviolet wavelengths, some of which have never been studied in detail. It will observe the hottest stars and seek traces of helium. The Ultraviolet Imaging Telescope, developed by NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., will provide wide-angle photographs of the sky. Images will be recorded on film, which will be developed following the mission. Much of what is seen eventually will be examined in greater detail by Hubble's telephoto eye. ``UIT sees the forest. Hubble studies the trees,'' Weiler said. The Wisconsin Ultraviolet Photo-Polarimeter Experiment _ WUPPE for short, pronounced whoopee _ will measure the brightness and orientation, or polarization, of ultraviolet light from stars. ``Polarization measurements in the ultraviolet have not yet been done,'' said Arthur Code, the telescope's principal investigator. ``I think we're going to have a lot of interesting data to really say `Whoopee!''' Because of their complexity, the ultraviolet instruments will be operated by Durrance and Parise _ the first payload specialists since Challenger exploded _ and mission specialists Robert Parker and Jeffrey Hoffman. The men will split 12-hour shifts. Astro's fourth scientific instrument is the Broad Band X-Ray Telescope, a Goddard project operated by computer commands sent from there. It will probe the elusive spectrum of X-rays and track remnants of exploding stars, or supernovas. So as not to disturb the telescopes' pointing systems, Columbia commander Vance Brand and pilot Guy Gardner will do their treadmill exercises _ one of several medical experiments _ when no observations are being made and none of the crew is sleeping.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Move Within 30 Miles of Liberian Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 4th graf, The government ..., to ADD comments by rebel spokesman. Pickup 5th graf pvs: On Saturday ...
DOC.TEXT: Rebel troops advanced to within 30 miles of this capital city Saturday, the closest they have reached since launching their invasion five months ago, Western diplomatic sources said. In Monrovia, about 500 members of the two tribes that have largely supported the rebels crowded into the local U.N. headquarters pleading for protection from attacks by government forces. In another development, Western diplomatic sources and shipping sources disputed a government claim that its forces had retaken the strategic port of Buchanan. The sources said rebel forces still hold the port. The government claimed Thursday to have retaken the port, 88 miles southeast of Monrovia, four days after rebels seized it. A rebel spokesman said there has been no fighting in Buchanan since a force of more than 1,000 National Patriotic Front rebels easily captured the city after most of the government garrison had fled. ``Someone in Monrovia is tooting his horn and continues to lie, to keep up the charade I suppose,'' said the spokesman, Tom Woewiyu, in a telephone interview late Saturday from his home in East Orange, N.J. Woewiyu, who spoke with The Associated Press upon returning from talks with State Department officials in Washington, said the United States is trying to get rebel and government officials to negotiate an end to the fighting. But the rebels will not open talks unless President Samuel Doe resigns and surrenders to the rebels to stand trial for ``murder, genocide, human rights abuses'' and other alleged crimes, Woewiyu said. On Saturday, rebel forces captured a roadblock from government forces outside the town of Kakata, 30 miles northeast of Monrovia, and briefly moved into the town before being driven out by government troops, the diplomatic sources said. They spoke on condition of anonymity. The sources also said rebels were seen near the international airport, 30 miles southeast of the capital of this West African nation. These advances are the closest the rebels have moved toward the capital since they began their attack on Dec. 24 from the Ivory Coast in a bid to overthrow Doe. The refugees gathered at the U.N. office Saturday were members of the Gio and Mano tribes that the government considers the main backers of the rebels. The refugees said many of their friends and relatives have been killed or detained. The government has denied persecuting any groups. Last week, the headless bodies of 10 men from the Gio and Mano tribes were found in Monrovia. Some of the wives of the victims blamed the government for the killings. The United States and other Western governments appealed to Liberians to end the ethnic violence and called on Doe to make sure those responsible for the killings were prosecuted. International organizations and the U.S. Congress earlier condemned government forces, saying they had killed hundreds of civilians in their efforts to defeat the rebels. At the U.N. office, Kortoe Dolo stood sobbing. ``They killed my brother. They killed him,'' he said. The body of his brother, Joseph, a delivery man for an electronics company, was found Friday in a Monrovia creek, Kortoe Dolo said. Joseph Dolo's wife, Kema, said two groups of armed soldiers came to their house Monday night, looted the home, raped her and abducted Joseph. One man at the U.N. headquarters, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he had seen between 300 and 500 young men from the Gio and Mano tribes being held at the Barclay army training center in central Monrovia. Michael Heyn, chief U.N. representative in Monrovia, said about 500 people from the Gio and Mano tribes were gathered in the U.N. compound looking for protection. He said talks were under way with the government to assure their safety. About 300 people had asked for help from the U.S. Embassy on Friday but were turned away. The rebels, led by former Doe aide Charles Taylor, say they want to bring an end to Doe's 10-year rule, which they claim is corrupt. However, Taylor has made it clear elections will not be held immediately if he takes power. The rebels have taken control of Nimba County, next to to the Ivorian and Guinean borders, and have moved south to the Atlantic Coast.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Seizes Fishing Boat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to CORRECT length of boat to 90 feet, sted 50 feet, DELETE reference in lead to Colombians swimming from vessel, UPDATE with five pounds of marijuana seized on shore, 12 arrested, ADD details. No pick up.
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard seized a 90-foot fishing vessel Saturday, searched it for drugs and arrested 12 people after a group was spotted throwing something off a nearby bridge, authorities said. No illegal drugs were found on the trawler, but the Coast Guard said in a statement it seized the vessel and towed it 50 miles north to San Francisco Bay for a more extensive search. Twelve men, seven on shore and five on the boat, were arrested, the statement said. All 12 carried identification as Colombians, but their nationalities had not been confirmed by early Sunday, Coast Guard Lt. Jim Wierzbicki said. About five pounds of marijuana was seized on shore after investigators combed a 20-mile stretch of coastline for drugs they suspect were dumped from the boat, the Coast Guard said. Three of the 12 people arrested were held for investigation of drug charges. The others were held for investigation of immigration violations, the San Mateo County Sheriff's Department said. Sheriff's deputies alerted the Coast Guard and the U.S. Customs Service after spotting several people on California Highway 1 throwing something over a bridge, authorities said. The deputies arrested seven people on or near the bridge and confiscated a bundle containing about five pounds of marijuana. An inflatable boat was found nearby. The Coast Guard initially identified the boat as 50 feet long.

DOC.HEAD: Precede HYDERABAD
Snipers Kill Nine in Karachi; Gunbattle Leaves 18 Dead in Hyderabad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to change dateline to Karachi, UPDATE with report of snipers slaying nine, other details. Pickup 3rd graf pvs: The battle ...
DOC.TEXT: Snipers opened fire simultaneously in different neighborhoods of this port city Sunday, killing nine people and wounding 25 in the latest outbreak of ethnic-related violence, police said. In the city of Hyderabad, about 150 miles to the north, thousands of security forces conducted house-to-house searches after a fierce gunbattle Saturday in the city's poorest neighborhood left at least 18 people dead and more than 200 wounded. Karachi and Hyderabad are the two main cities in Sindh Provice, where a militant faction of the Mohajir Qami Movement has been clashing with supporters of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto. In Karachi, the province's largest city, gunmen fired at pedestrians and motor vehicles for about half an hour in different neighborhoods, police said. Authorities refused to say who might be responsible for the attacks, which began around 6 a.m. ``This could only be a well-organized plan,'' said one senior police officer, speaking on condition of anonymity. In Hyderabad, police and doctors at a local hospital said they expected the death toll to rise as ambulances picked up bodies that lined the narrow streets of the old walled city, a winding congested maze of mud brick houses and shanties. The battle, which lasted for more than two hours, forced authorities to cancel a two-hour curfew break, they said. As security troops cordoned off the area and prepared to conduct house-to-house searches, the fighting spread to other parts of Hyderabad, the second-largest city in southern Sindh Province. According to official count, at least 75 people have been killed and hundreds more wounded since May 15 in ethnic-related violence and indiscriminate shootings in this city of 3 million people. No one has claimed responsibility for the bloodshed. Police blame a militant faction of the Mohajir Qami Movement, a small political party representing descendants of Moslem Indians who immigrated to Pakistan during the 1947 partition of the subcontinent. The movement is demanding recognition as Pakistan's fifth nationality, along with the Punjabis, Pathans, Sindhis and Baluch. Witnesses said Saturday's gun battle erupted as security forces moved into the old city, home to about 100,000 people, searching for weapons. The residents, most of them Mohajirs, apparently thought rival Sindhi nationalists planned to attack and opened fire with automatic weapons, killing two officers and wounding seven others before security forces returned fire, witnesses said. About 2,000 combat-ready paramilitary units, riot police and rangers have patrolled the city to try to contain the violence. Army-supervised curfews have become a way of life. Thousands of security force members swept through Hyderabad and across Sindh on Thursday and Friday and arrested more than 800 suspects. Police said they included members of the Mohajir Qami Movement and Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party. In recent years the province has been the site of constant kidnappings and assassinations. More than 2,000 people have been killed. The worst carnage occurred on Sept. 30 in Hyderabad, when at least 300 people were killed in a massacre that lasted only 23 minutes. Those suspected of organizing the killings have not been arrested, fueling fears that the problem is beyond the government's control. In Karachi, the provincial capital, ethnic strife and political rivalries have turned Pakistan's largest city into a battleground. The main combatants are Ms. Bhutto's supporters and members of the Mohajir Qami Movement. Opposition politicians have accused Ms. Bhutto's 17-month-old government of failing to curb the violence in her home province. She has said the provincial government has not done enough to curb the escalating violence and lawlessness. But she accused neighboring India of stirring up trouble in Sindh and in the eastern province of Punjab. New Delhi blames Pakistan for violent separatist movements in Indian Punjab and Jammu-Kashmir, India's only state that has a Moslem majority.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Supreme Court Rejects Appeal In Nuclear Spy Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court Sunday rejected former nuclear technician Mordechai Vanunu's appeal of his conviction for treason and espionage resulting from his leaks about Israel's nuclear weapons program to a London newspaper. The three-judge panel announced their decision, but it was read behind closed doors in keeping with the secrecy surrounding Vanunu's case since he was arrested in 1986 after disappearing in London. The judges did not make public their reasons for rejecting the appeal. The case received international attention because Vanunu claimed he had been drugged and kidnapped by Israeli agents just before publication of articles in The Sunday Times of London based on his disclosures. The newspaper reported that Israel had stockpiled 100 nuclear weapons and had the ability to make atomic, neutron and hydrogen bombs. It said this arsenal made Israel the world's sixth largest nuclear power. Israel has never responded directly to allegations about its nuclear capacity, but has said it will not be the first country to introduce atomic weapons into the Middle East. Israeli officials refused to disclose how Vanunu was brought to Israel but said no British laws were broken. Vanunu's brother, Meir, said Vanunu was lured from London to Rome by an American woman who promised him sex. In Rome, he was abducted by Israeli agents and spirited home, Meir said. Vanunu, 36, a former technician at Israel's nuclear facility in Dimona, was convicted in March 1988 and sentenced to 18 years in prison. In his appeal, Vanunu maintained that speaking to a newspaper does not constitute espionage or treason. During his trial, Vanunu testified he made his revelations to the newspaper to alert the Middle East and the world to the dangers of nuclear weapons, not for personal gain or out of a desire to harm his country. The maximum punishment for the treason and espionage charges is life, but the judges took into account Vanunu's indications that he regretted his actions. Vanunu was brought to the Supreme Court Sunday in a white van with the windows covered so he could not be seen by photographers or reporters. The Supreme Court said it would hear arguments within 30 days on whether to make public its full decision on Vanunu's appeal. Vanunu also has 30 days to appeal the decision to a larger Supreme Court panel or ask for a reduction in his sentence. He has 14 years left to serve since his time in jail before his conviction was counted as time served. He is jailed in the Ashkelon Prison in a private cell. The three judges who rejected the appeal were Meir Shamgar, Dov Levin and Eliezer Goldberg.

DOC.HEAD: Six Killed in Shootout at Yerevan Train Station
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd, `Ten soldiers...' and 11th, `Tass said...' with 1 graf each to CORRECT that only one civilian was wounded. Pickup 12th, `It also...'
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen opened fire on a Soviet military patrol at Yerevan's main train station early Sunday, and the soldiers returned fire, killing six of the attackers, the official Tass news agency said. Ten soldiers and a bystander were wounded in the exchange of fire in the capital of the Caucasus republic Armenia, Tass said. No one claimed responsibility for the attack, but it was probably carried out by militants involved in the bitter struggle between Armenia and neighboring Azerbaijan for control of the Nagorno-Karabakh region. In more than two years, several hundred people have been killed in the violence, and hundreds of thousands have been forced to flee their homes. Soviet soldiers have been sent into both of the republics in an effort to quell the violence. Satenik Haramazyan, a spokeswoman for the Armenian National Movement political organization, confirmed in a telephone interview from Yerevan that the shootout had taken place, but she said no details were available. She said the movement did not know who attacked the soldiers. The movement held a rally on Opera Square in downtown Yerevan on Sunday afternoon to tell citizens what it knew about the attack, she said. The soldiers were returning early Sunday morning from escorting a train to Kafan, a city 120 miles southeast of Yerevan in the corner of the Caucasus republic, when the shooting broke out, Tass said. The soldiers were attacked by a group of up to 15 armed men, it said. Soldiers, ``using their right to use weapons to rebuff an attack, returned fire. As a result of the exchange of fire, five of the attackers were killed and two were wounded,'' the news report said. ``One of the wounded died soon.'' Tass said three of the 10 soldiers were seriously injured. One bystander who received bullet wounds in the shootout also was taken to the hospital, it said, but the report did not say how seriously he was wounded. It also did not say where in the train station the shooting occurred, and officials at the station could not immediately be reached for more details. The shootout came three days after militants fired on soldiers at military checkpoints and on patrol in Nagorno-Karabakh, killing one soldier and wounding four. Tass said one attacker was killed and six were wounded by soldiers. Both Armenian and Azerbaijani militants obtained large supplies of weapons during fighting between the two sides that occurred in early January and have rebuffed efforts by officials to take back many of the guns. The dispute between the neighboring republics is over Nagorno-Karabkh, an enclave located in Azerbaijan but that is mostly Armenian. In an effort to stop the violence, Moscow took over administrative control of Nagorno-Karabakh in January 1989, and Armenians now demand Moscow's relinquish control. Armenia is predominantly Christian, while Azerbaijan is mostly Moslem.

DOC.HEAD: Jews Anguish Over Desecrations, Welcome Shows of Solidarity
DOC.TEXT: May has been a month of horror for Europe's Jews, but also a month of hope and healing. A wave of anti-Semitic threats, desecrations and vandalism across the continent, including the gruesome mutilation of a corpse at a Jewish cemetery in France, provoked revulsion and reawakened old fears. Yet the same incidents inspired unprecedented displays of solidarity and reconciliation, suggesting to some Jews that much of Europe had learned the lessons of the Holocaust. Francois Mitterrand, marching with a throng of Parisians protesting the desecration at Carpentras, became the first president of postwar France to join a public demonstration. King Baudouin became the first Belgian monarch to invite rabbis to the royal palace, where they heard his words of sympathy and concern. Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere of East Germany broke with the ousted Communists, who had denied any role in the Nazi extermination of 6 million Jews, and pledged to seek reconciliation with the international Jewish community. In Oberammergau, West Germany, the centuries-old Passion Play about the suffering of Jesus was performed in a rewritten version, shorn of anti-Semitic passages. For some Jews, such gestures were not enough. The American Jewish Congress took a full-page advertisement Tuesday in the International Herald Tribune asking Europe's political and religious leaders to ``speak out, clearly and forthrightly'' against ``the ugly cadences of anti-Semitic slogans and threats.'' Much of Europe has been plagued with relatively minor anti-Semitic incidents, notably Nazi-oriented graffiti, but Jews had not anticipated the shock of Carpentras, home of France's oldest synagogue. Relatives arriving at the cemetery May 10 found 34 tombs vandalized and the recently buried body of Felix Germon, 81, dug up and impaled on an umbrella handle. Since then, Jewish cemeteries and synagogues have been desecrated in several other towns in France and in Hungary, East Berlin, London and Naples, Italy. In Romania over the past two weeks, vandals desecrated about 70 graves in three cities and nearly half belonged to Jews. In the Transylvanian town of Tirgu Mures, 28 Jewish graves were vandalized. The Carpentras case has not been solved, despite the efforts of more than 60 police investigators. Most of those arrested in connection with other recent desecrations in France have been ``skinheads'' _ youths with close-cropped hair and vaguely fascist ideologies. There has been no proof of involvement by France's extreme-right National Front, whose brash leader, Jean-Marie Le Pen, has been accused of inciting racist and anti-Semitic feelings. Analysts in several European countries suggest the outbreak of anti-Semitic activity is tied to a broader resentment of immigrants and fear of economic turmoil. ``Historically, Western Europe was a white continent,'' said Tullia Zevi, a Jewish leader in Italy. ``Now it is becoming multi-ethnic, like the United States. ``This is creating feelings of great insecurity and uneasiness. There is a resumption of ancient prejudices against Jews, combined with a new form of racism projected against the new immigrant minority.'' Even though most Jewish families in France go back generations, they suffer their compatriots' worries, said Bob Goldman, European director for the U.S.-based Anti-Defamation League. ``The handiest target are the Jews,'' Goldman said in a telephone interview. ``A lot of people traditionally see them as foreign and different.'' In parts of Eastern Europe, growing nationalism has stirred fears of resurgent anti-Semitism. Soccer fans in the Soviet republic of Uzbekistan were said to have targeted Jewish homes during a rampage May 2. An extreme nationalist Russian group called Pamyat _ or Memory _ has spread propaganda blaming Jews for social ills and urging a new ``final solution.'' ``The Russian people is not really more anti-Semitic than any other, but with the constant irritation of shortages and life getting worse, it's becoming meaner and more irritable,'' said Jewish activist Natasha Stonov. ``Everything is covered with gasoline, and all it takes is a match.'' About 1.5 million Jews live in the Soviet Union and the number is dropping steadily because of emigration. The rest of Europe has only that many in all, a fraction of the total before World War II. A survey by the Foundation for Combating Anti-Semitism of Rotterdam, published this week, indicated surprisingly little evidence of anti-Semitism in Hungary, Romania and even in Poland, despite the controversy about a Roman Catholic convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp. Richard Stein, foundation chairman, said the conditions were worst in France and Italy, where there is extensive anti-Semitism beneath the surface. After Carpentras, many French people invoked images of Nazism's rise before World War II, but prominent sociologist Pierre-Andre Taguieff said comparisons with the 1930s ``are catastrophic and wrong.'' ``Today, anti-Semites are marginal,'' he wrote in an essay. ``They feel persecuted. They refuse to admit what they are.'' The mass march by Mitterrand and up to 200,000 compatriots, many of them non-Jews wearing yellow Stars of David, ``would be unthinkable'' in the 1930s, he said. France's chief rabbi, Joseph Sitruk, sounded a similar note at Carpentras, when he led more than 10,000 people of all faiths in a service at the cemetery the weekend after the desecration. ``France is not anti-Semitic,'' the rabbi preached. ``What a beautiful lesson is given here this morning. I dare to say it _ what happiness. What happiness to see France identifying with our suffering.''

DOC.HEAD: Far-Right Leader Called `Beast' and `Devil'
With AM-Europe-Anti-Semitism, Bjt
LaserPhoto PAR1
DOC.TEXT: Jean-Marie Le Pen has been accused of anti-Semitism and xenophobia in his crusade to keep France French. The press calls him a ``devil,'' but Le Pen doesn't care. ``If I told you it gives me pleasure, would you be surprised?'' he says with a grin. After 30 years of battle in the public arena, Le Pen refuses to yield now. ``I'm a man with a mission,'' he said. Alluding to death threats, he added: ``If I fall, I will have accomplished it.'' Le Pen and his National Front fear ``colonization'' by foreigners. They want to expel immigrants and enact new anti-immigration laws. To the accusations of racism, anti-Semitism and xenophobia, Le Pen replies that he is simply a patriot who says in public what other people think in private. After the discovery May 10 of the desecration of the Jewish cemetery in Carpentras and mutilation of a corpse, Interior Minister Pierre Joxe accused Le Pen of fostering hate. Le Pen was present only in effigy at a huge protest march in Paris that attracted all the main political parties. ``I am Carpentras'' read a sign on the effigy. ``It leaves me rather cold,'' Le Pen said, settling into a chair in the study of his home in St. Cloud, a suburb of Paris. ``I have the calm of an old soldier. I've often seen the whites of the enemy's eyes.'' For him, the enemy is the political establishment supported by the media, which he claims echo its lies. He says the desecration at Carpentras was a plot carried out by professionals to discredit him. ``There is one thing I'm sure of: It is that I'm not guilty and the National Front is not guilty,'' Le Pen said. ``I don't know who did it, but I know who didn't do it.'' Like a television preacher, Le Pen knows how to pump a crowd. He struts, cajoles and rages, tempering his street-smart edge with quotes from Pascal or Latin citations. He is silver-haired, physically imposing, and even detractors acknowledge he has charisma. The 61-year-old Breton, whom the French press calls the ``beast'' or the ``devil,'' thrives on controversy. ``Democracy is a debate, a combat of ideas,'' he said recently. ``It's not a parade of arm-chair philosophers with good intentions.'' On a bookshelf sits a portrait of Le Pen wearing the black bandanna he once affected to cover the eye he lost in a street fight defending a parliamentary deputy. A former paratrooper and Foreign Legionnaire who fought in Indochina and Algeria, he now fights many of his battles in court. Le Pen, a deputy in the European Parliament, has been convicted three times and fined for making remarks about Jews or the Holocaust, but he denies being racist or anti-Semitic. He says he has won 30 slander suits against the press. ``Me? Racist? It's a gag, a gag,'' he boomed. ``But I'm not for the melting pot. I'm for the defense of one's culture. I'd despair if I found the culture of Brooklyn in France.'' Of Jews, he said: ``If they are French, there's no problem; I'm not anti-Semitic.'' On Wednesday, a court fined Le Pen for saying in 1987 that the Nazi gas chambers were a ``detail of World War II history.'' The Justice Ministry has succeeded in getting Le Pen's parliamentary immunity lifted to prosecute him for two other remarks: a play on words in 1988 linking the name of a Cabinet minister to Nazi crematory ovens and his assertion last year that the ``Jewish international'' was partly responsible for the ``anti-national spirit.'' ``Who is charged to say what one can and cannot say in a free country?'' he said. Le Pen founded the National Front in 1972 and remained obscure until the party broke through in 1984, getting 11 percent of the vote in European Parliament elections. He startled France in 1988 by winning 14 percent in the first round of presidential voting. Politicians of all sorts have scrambled to either outmaneuver or accommodate him, or to woo his followers with tough talk on immigration. By getting the law on voter representation changed, the government of former Premier Jacques Chirac managed to reduce the National Front's parliamentary seats from 33 to one. Since Carpentras, which set off a wave of anti-Semitic acts, Le Pen is being denounced with greater vigor than ever. He is ``a man dangerous for national unity, for civil peace,'' declared Chirac, now a conservative leader. He ``boos the name of Gen. de Gaulle and applauds that of the Nazi Schoenhuber,'' Chirac said. Franz Schoenhuber, a former member of the Waffen SS, is a far-right colleague of Le Pen in the European Parliament. At least six cities, including La Trinite-Sur-Mer, his hometown in Brittany, recently denied Le Pen and his followers meeting space. Le Pen compares himself to a fire chief racing across town, sirens blaring, in time to contain the blaze. ``Everybody says, `See that racist fire. It's fire chief Le Pen who is guilty. You can even see all the noise he makes with his big horn,''' he said. Racism is not increasing in France, Le Pen said, ``but there is increasing fear tied to insecurity toward foreigners and nobody dares say so. Everyone is afraid to be called a racist.'' He read from newspaper clippings of attacks on French citizens by people with Arab names. ``Of course, I'm afraid,'' he said. ``If Europe is Europe, it's because it has resisted'' conquest by outsiders. Le Pen plans to run for president again in 1995. Citing audience ratings after his recent appearance on a political talk show, he said: ``I had 13 percent ... and Brigitte Bardot had just 5.4 percent'' on a competing channel.

DOC.HEAD: Squatter Community Surrenders After Day Of Rioting
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of police officers used chain saws on Sunday to cut through barricades and evict more than 100 squatters who had occupied an abandoned office complex for four years. No violence was reported during the eviction, which occurred one day after the squatters left the complex for several hours to ransack nearby shops and fight running street battles with riot police. The squatters rioted Saturday to protest a court ruling ordering them out of the former Wolters-Noordhof publishing complex by Monday. They hurled firebombs and bricks at police after ransacking two cafes and a nearby office. Eleven rioters were reported arrested. Piles of charred refuse from Saturday's disturbance littered the streets around the charred walls of the brick complex where the eviction occurred.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect Arrested For Trying to Smuggle Heroin to U.S.
DOC.TEXT: A Hong Kong man preparing to board a flight for New York on Sunday was arrested when authorities found $2.5 million worth of heroin concealed in the false bottom of a suitcase he was carrying, police said. The 21-year-old man, whose name was withheld, will be charged in court on Tuesday with drug trafficking, authorities said. The arrest and the confiscation of the 5.5 pounds of heroin occurred at the British colony's Kaitak International Airport.

DOC.HEAD: Antique Jewels Stolen From Gallery Near Louvre
DOC.TEXT: Three armed robbers stole $900,000 worth of antique jewelry Sunday from a luxury shopping arcade across from the Louvre art museum, police said. The robbery occurred about 11 a.m., as many of the 240 antique shops, art galleries and jewelry stores in the arcade _ known as the Louvre des Antiquaires _ were opening for abbreviated Sunday business hours. The masked gunmen surprised the owner of one of the jewelry shops as he arrived for work, completed the robbery within a few minutes and fled without firing shots. Police were investigating.

DOC.HEAD: Filipino Airman Kills Seven, Wounds 12 at Wake
DOC.TEXT: A Filipino airman opened fire with an assault rifle on mourners attending a wake for a colleague in the northern Philippines, killing seven people and wounding 12, air force officials said Sunday. Officials said they had not determined the motive for Saturday's attack, which occurred in the town of Bacarra, 250 miles north of Manila. Authorities identified the suspect in the slayings as Carmelo Dugay, 36, who was assigned to a radar station in the northern province of Ilocos Norte. Dugay had been resting in a room after guard duty, but emerged with an M-16 assault rifle and opened fire on the crowd of mourners in a house, officials said. The gunman fled after the attack. Col. Avelino Abiol, an air force spokesman, said the dead included a retired lieutenant, five civilians and an airman who died later at a hospital. Among the wounded were two airmen and 10 civilians, Abiol said.

DOC.HEAD: Family Reunites After 30 Years
DOC.TEXT: The Jones family is back together. But it took three decades of searching and hoping. ``It's all so fresh and today is the day,'' Jim Ahlers, who was born James Thomas Jones, said Saturday at the family reunion in Callaway Park. ``We made it.'' In 1960, his mother was arrested for child neglect, and he and his 10 brothers and sisters were taken to a children's home in Hamilton, Ohio. There they were separated according to age and sex, and later they were adopted. Ralph Jones began his search when he left the orphanage in 1961. ``Now they're all grown up,'' he said. ``I never thought I'd see the day.'' Most of the siblings _ their mother has died _ had already been reunited before Saturday's reunion. But two of the boys remained unfound. ``I remember all of them,'' said LaVern Lang, the oldest of the siblings. ``Up until Jimmy found us this year we thought that would be it. We thought we would never find Dennis or Jimmy.'' But Jimmy Ahlers, 34, found his family this month, and one week later the family found the youngest sibling, Dennis Brown, who was an infant at the time of the separation. ``I don't have words for it. My feelings are running wild. It's starting to sink in a little bit,'' Brown said. A faded photograph of the children was the only reminder some of them had of their earlier lives. Ahlers said the search isn't over. ``My grandmother is alive and holding me in the original photo. I want to meet her,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Animal Protectionists Staging March to Show `We're Not Lunatics'
DOC.TEXT: The people who believe animals should be treated more humanely are about to stage their first national event, a ``March for the Animals'' intended to demonstrate that their movement is becoming a mainstream cause. ``We will march peacefully and non-violently to show America that we are reasonable and rational people and not a bunch of lunatics,'' says one of the organizers, Peter Linck, executive director of the National Alliance for Animal Legislation. ``Our purpose is to unify ourselves and educate the country and raise the nation's consciousness,'' he said. The march, from the Ellipse behind the White House to the Capitol, is scheduled to take place June 10. Linck said the animal protection movement is the country's fastest-growing cause. The Humane Society of the United States, an old-line group which describes itself as ``moderate,'' has seen its membership increase fourfold _ from 325,000 in 1985 to 1.2 million today. Another group, Friends of Animals, has grown quickly too _ from 60,000 members three years ago to double that number _ but president Priscilla Feral said more significant is the way the concerns of animal lovers are being shared by people not involved in the movement. ``It is absolutely normal now to hear people talking about whether to buy a fur coat, or take the kids to the circus or about the campaign to save the dolphins,'' Ms. Feral said in an interview recently. She said the growth of the 1975 Friends of the Animals tuna boycott was a factor in the decision in April by the makers of StarKist, Bumble Bee and Chicken of the Sea brands to stop buying tuna captured with fishing nets that also trap, and kill, dolphins. Linck said thousands of participants from all 50 states and at least half a dozen foreign countries are expected at the march. At 30, Linck is a veteran of the animal protection movement. In college, he switched from a pre-veterinarian course of study to law so he could lobby for animal welfare issues. He is co-chairman of the demonstration with Tom Regan, author of ``The Case for Animal Rights.'' The march is sponsored by hundreds of local and national groups. The animal protection movement represents divergent views _ some activists are meat-eaters and some, like Linck, decline even to wear shoes made of leather. Some believe the use of animals in biomedical research is acceptable and some do not. ``But a reverence for life would be their common concern,'' said Linck. He said some in the movement believe that all creatures, even insects, ``have an inherent right to live and should be respected to the highest degree possible, while others would draw the line at mammals.'' The organizers have lined up a number of pro-animal celebrities to address the crowd _ ranging from cartoonist Berke Breathed to professional basketball player James Donaldson _ and anticipate hearing from a number of sympathetic politicians too. The political speakers have not been announced because they are still being recruited. One prominent speaker will be Australian philosopher Peter Singer, author of ``Animal Liberation,'' who is considered ``the father of the modern animal rights movement.'' Another speaker will be Mayor Bill Stirling of Aspen, Colo., backer of a proposal to ban the sale of fur in Aspen. Voters rejected the ban, by a 2-1 margin, in February, but supporters claimed a victory by bringing national attention to the issue. The march's sponsoring organizations have a variety of goals _ more humane farm practices; abolishing hunting as a sport; limiting the use of animals for testing medications, cosmetics and other products; halting fur sales; banning the use of the steel leg hold trap, described as a cruel way to catch wild animals for their furs; and having pets spayed and neutered to prevent overpopulation. On the day following their demonstration, the marchers plan to lobby Congress in support of 60 animal protection bills that have been introduced, but will concentrate on three proposed measures. One would prohibit the use of an animal test that measures pesticides, cosmetics, drugs, weedkillers and household products for toxicity; opponents say the test is unnecessary and causes suffering or death for up to 5 million animals a year. Another would prohibit the practice of confining veal calves in small crates and the practice of feeding them a diet deficient in solid food and iron to produce white meat. A third would prohibit hunting and trapping of wildlife for sport or commercial purposes on national wildlife refuges.

DOC.HEAD: North Korea to Turn Over Remains of U.S. Soldiers on Memorial Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Transfer of remains scheduled for 10 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: The remains of five American soldieres killed more than 35 years ago in the Korean War and held since then by North Korea will begin their final journey home on Memorial Day. A U.S. congressional delegation arrived in Seoul Sunday to arrange for the first return of U.S. Korean War dead from Communist North Korea since 1954. The return of the remains is widely seen as a gesture by North Korea to improve relations with the United States. The two countries do not have diplomatic relations. The eight-man U.S. delegation, led by Rep. G.V. ``Sonny'' Montgomery, D-Miss., chairman of the House Veterans Affairs Committee, will travel Monday to the truce village of Panmunjom to receive the remains. Panmunjom is in the Demilitarized Zone separating South Korea and North Korea. The congressmen arrived on a special flight that landed at an airport outside Seoul. Reporters were not allowed to cover their arrival. U.S. military officials in Seoul said Montgomery would receive the remains after signing a document with a North Korean lawmaker. The delegation will then turn the remains over to the U.S. military, which plans to send them to a forensic laboratory in Honolulu for identification. The U.S. Defense Department said the North Koreans identified two of the dead as Army 1st Lt. Jack J. Saunders, 27, of Ogden, Utah, and Army Cpl. Arthur Leo Seaton, 20, whose family lived in Chester, Pa. Both soldiers were listed as missing in action in February 1951, the Pentagon said. North Korean diplomats assigned to the United Nations told The Associated Press Saturday that a pilot also was believed to be among the dead. There were large-scale returns of remains in 1953 and 1954. Then, after years of no returns, the North Koreans announced May 14 that they would turn over the remains of five Americans on Memorial Day. Ho Jong, North Korea's deputy permanent representative at its U.N. mission, said the Communist government in Pyongyang was prepared to discuss returning more. He said the move was an ``eloquent illustration'' of North Korea's willingness to ``settle pending issues with the U.S. government in a good way.'' The American-led United Nations Command in Seoul said more than 9,000 U.N. Command military personnel were unaccounted for after the war ended, including 8,177 Americans and soldiers from Canada, Australia and England. Official figures show that 33,629 U.S. soldiers were killed and 103,284 wounded in the war. The U.N. Command includes the United States and 15 other nations that fought on South Korea's side after North Korean forces invaded across the 38th parallel dividing the Korean Peninsula on June 25, 1950. The three-year conflict left more than 1 million people dead and another 1 million wounded. North Korea acknowledged for the first time in January 1988 that it was still holding the remains of U.N. Command war dead. The North Koreans agreed to begin negotiations on returning the remains a few weeks later, but then canceled the talks after the United States accused North Korea of sponsoring terrorism in connection with the bombing of a South Korean civilian airliner. The Korean Air jet disappeared off the coast of Burma in November 1987, and all 115 people aboard the plane died. A woman who was among the passengers on an early leg of the flight was arrested later and testified that she had planted a time bomb on the plane on orders from North Korean leaders who wanted to scare people away from the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul. North Korea denied the allegations. Other members of the congressional delegation are Democrats Frank McCloskey of Indiana, James Bilbray of Nevada, Bob Traxler of Michigan and Ben Campbell of Colorado, and Republicans Bob Stump of Arizona, Curt Weldon of Pennsylvania and Gerald Solomon of New York.

DOC.HEAD: Half New Drugs Had Unanticipated Side Effects
DOC.TEXT: The faster new drugs are rushed to market the more likely they will produce severe unanticipated side effects, congressional auditors conclude in a report saying half the new products introduced over a decade had to be relabeled with new warnings. Certain classes of drugs _ heart, anti-inflammatory, psychopharmacologic, dermatologic and antibiotic _ were most likely to have serious post-approval reactions, the General Accounting Office said in a report prepared for release Sunday. Especially ``troubling,'' said the GAO, was that drugs for use by children were twice as likely to have reports of serious unanticipated reactions after their approval by the Food and Drug Administration. The GAO reviewed label changes for the 209 new drugs that were approved from 1976 to 1985 to determine the seriousness of additional risks identified after the drugs were approved. The study found that of the 198 drugs for which data could be found, 102, or 51.5 percent, had reports of serious adverse reactions. Those reactions were defined as leading to hospitalization or increased length of hospitalization, or resulting in severe or permanent disability or death. Six of the drugs were withdrawn from the market and labels on the rest were changed to add major warnings or precautions for their use, or to restrict for whom the drug should be prescribed, the report said. Rep. Ted Weiss, D-N.Y., who requested the report, said shortcomings in the FDA's drug approval process may be responsible for serious adverse reactions. ``Serious and unanticipated adverse reactions are certainly a risk we must accept when FDA shortens the review time for experimental drugs to treat immediately life-threatening illnesses such as AIDS and cancer,'' Weiss said. But for less serious diseases, ``this may be too high a price to pay for shorter approval times,'' he said. ``By failing to systematically use evidence of post-approval risks linked to drugs already on the market, FDA may be overlooking problems with similar drugs under review at the agency but not yet approved,'' Weiss said. The FDA, in comments included in the report, said the GAO's review was ``not methodologically sound'' and would ``unnecessarily alarm consumers.'' ``Even the most extensive pre-market testing cannot cover all possible circumstances,'' said FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit. ``Testing perhaps 3,000 people over months or years won't always identify a rare reaction unfolding over a long time or affecting perhaps just one person in 10,000.'' He said that is why FDA monitors reports of adverse drug reactions after a product is marketed. It can take as long as eight to 10 years for a drug to move through the FDA approval process, beginning when a company applies for permission to test a new product in humans. The first studies test the drug's safety in a small number of people. Later, the drug is tested for effectiveness. If after the FDA reviews all the data _ which on average takes 29 months, according to GAO _ the drug may be approved for marketing. Because the pre-approval testing involves small numbers of patients, more information about the drug usually surfaces after the drug is approved and distributed widely. The FDA monitors reports of adverse reactions and sometimes requires post-approval research as a condition of approval. The time between a drug's approval and a post-marketing label change is five years or more, the GAO report said. The congressional auditors recommended that FDA establish a systematic procedure to assure that serious reactions discovered after a drug's approval are evaluated to identify possible risks with similar drugs not yet on the market.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Financing of Mexican Drug Strike Teams Urged
DOC.TEXT: Three members of the House Armed Services Committee want the Bush administration to finance the Mexican government's mobile strike forces that sweep in on drug traffickers at landing strips. After inspecting drug war command centers, the lawmakers said in a report released Sunday that officials have largely succeeded in combatting the flow of drugs across the Mexican border via aircraft. ``We have forced the drug industry to look for new routes and new methods,'' the lawmakers said. Radar is capable of tracking aircraft carrying drugs to landing sites in northern Mexico but enforcement officials are unable to get there before the drugs are dispersed. Mexico ``now has a handful of mobile strike forces located in northern Mexico designed expressly to do what we are suggesting _ move in swiftly for the kill at the landing sites,'' the lawmakers said. They suggested that the United States provide the funds for the Mexican strike teams. No specific totals were provided. The report, in the form of a May 23 letter to House Armed Services Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., was written by Reps. Nicholas Mavroules, D-Mass., who chairs the panel's investigations subcommittee, Lane Evans, D-Ill., and Jim McCrery, R-La. The lawmakers said an alternative to U.S. financing of Mexican strike teams would be increasing the U.S. Border Patrol, which now has 3,900 officers. However, ``even a doubling or tripling of the manpower along the border would be unlikely to make a huge dent in the volume of drugs crossing the border,'' they said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Popularity Soars in Survey
With AM-Poll-Method
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union's popularity has soared in the United States since the last superpower summit, and Americans increasingly support U.S. military cuts to reflect the lessened tensions, a survey found. As President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev prepare to meet in Washington this week, the national Media General-Associated Press poll found both leaders continuing to command great popularity among Americans. Gorbachev slipped only slightly from his overall rating in a similar poll before the last summit in December, even though a third of the respondents now think less highly of him because of his crackdown on Lithuania. Most striking in the new survey were growing expressions of good will toward America's old Cold War foe. Forty-one percent of the respondents said they held favorable views of the Soviet Union, well up from 24 percent last November and 15 percent in a 1987 survey. Fourteen percent of the respondents in the new poll had unfavorable opinions of the Soviet Union, and 41 percent had a neutral view. In another measure of growing trust, a relatively low 29 percent believed the Soviets seek to dominate the world. That fear factor stood at 35 percent last November and 50 percent in a CBS News-New York Times poll a year ago. The new Media General-AP survey was conducted by telephone May 11-20 among a random sample of 1,143 adults across the country. It had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points. The summit starts Wednesday amid continuing upheaval in the communist world. Gorbachev is pushing reforms of the Soviet system while struggling to contain independence movements in some of the Soviet republics. His Eastern European allies, once viewed as puppets, largely have abandoned communism. Possibly because of Gorbachev's difficulties, the survey found some sense that the initiative in superpower relations has shifted to Bush. In November, 41 percent said Gorbachev was doing more than Bush to reduce tensions, but in the new survey that fell to 33 percent. At the same time, those saying Bush was doing more to ease tensions rose from 29 percent in November to 38 percent now. The rest were unsure. Similarly, 54 percent said Bush was doing enough to encourage Soviet reforms _ up from 46 percent in November _ and 33 percent said he was being too cautious, down from 40 percent in November. Again the rest were unsure. In view of the lessened tensions, 50 percent in the new survey said the United States should reduce its military spending significantly, up from 41 percent who favored such cuts last November. Additionally, nearly four in 10 said the United States should immediately begin reducing its forces in Western Europe. While still a minority, that was up from 25 percent in November. The poll found some lingering suspicion of the Soviets. Half said the Soviet Union cannot be trusted to live up to arms control agreements _ about the same as in November, but down from 61 percent a year ago. On Lithuania, 46 percent said the breakaway Baltic republic should back off from its claim of independence from the Soviet Union and hold negotiations, while 31 percent said it should push its claim. The rest had no opinion. But there was support for gradual independence for the Baltic states. Fifty-seven percent favored the actions of Lithuania and Latvia, which have claimed independence, while just 8 percent favored the actions of Estonia, which wants independence but has not formally claimed it. Gorbachev has responded to Lithuania's claim by denying it shipments of oil and other supplies. While 34 percent said the embargo has made them think less highly of Gorbachev, 48 percent said it had not changed their view. Overall, 63 percent had a favorable impression of Gorbachev and 69 percent held a favorable view of Bush. As in earlier surveys, Gorbachev outpolled Bush, 79-68 percent, among the best-educated respondents, those with postgraduate schooling. An overwhelming 75 percent of all respondents approved of the way Bush is handling relations with the Soviet Union. Media General Inc., a communications company based in Richmond, Va., publishes the Richmond Times-Dispatch, the Richmond News Leader, the Tampa (Fla.) Tribune and the Winston-Salem (N.C.) Journal, and operates TV stations WXFL in Tampa, WCBD in Charleston, S.C., and WJKS in Jacksonville, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Stunt Pilot Killed In Crash At Air Show
DOC.TEXT: A stunt plane crashed in flames while trying a rollover maneuver during an air show, killing the pilot, as 1,000 stunned spectators watched, authorities said. Macon County Coroner Hal Bentley said Albert Butler, 28, of Houston was killed in the crash Saturday evening at the annual Memorial Day air show. There were no other injuries. ``It shocked the crowd pretty good, especially when the fire covered that big area,'' Bentley said. Spectators were about 300 yards from the crash site. Butler, a member of Negro Airmen International, was ``trying to attempt a rollover, a trick maneuver,'' Bentley said. ``He was kind of low and it just went down.'' Federal Aviation Administration investigators were at the scene Sunday, he said. Witnesses said two planes were in the air when one came in low over the airfield, did a roll and dropped. The pilot of the second plane was not even aware the other one had crashed until after he landed, Bentley said. The annual air show is held as a tribute to black pilots who were trained at Tuskegee during World War II, when the Air Force was segregated. Pilots from different chapters of the Negro Airmen International take part in the show each year, said Assistant Police Chief John Meadows.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Weakness in the Union, Gorbachev Remains Strong
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 5th graf pvs, bgng: A Washington, to UPDATE with Media General-AP poll
DOC.TEXT: The economy is in shambles. Republics erupt in explosive ethnic quarrels; others try to secede. Comrades squabble over what is to be done _ and do nothing. Yet Mikhail S. Gorbachev not only survives but is championed around the world as a hero of epic proportion. In the five years of his reign, he has ended the Cold War, taken the first steps toward nuclear disarmament, pulled his army out of Afghanistan and begun the withdrawal of Soviet troops from foreign soil. Tens of millions of his countrymen and millions more in the former Soviet satellite states of Eastern Europe have been freed from totalitarian rule. ``I think,'' observed a Soviet teacher who recently returned from her first trip to the West, ``he is more popular abroad than he is at home.'' Two polls released Sunday lent support to that assertion. A Washington Post-ABC News poll said 73 percent of 1,526 American adults surveyed last week said they had a ``favorable impression'' of Gorbachev, with 25 percent responding ``unfavorable.'' A Media General-Associated Press survey, taken May 11-20 among 1,143 adults nationwide, found that 63 percent had a favorable impression of the Soviet leader. Both polls had a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points. At home, however, Gorbachev is no hero to many Soviets understandably preoccupied with the issues of everyday life: the food and ordinary goods they can't buy; the critical housing shortage that denies them simple comfort and privacy; the rising crime rate and ethnic strife that make them fearful for their families and meager possessions. He has pleaded futilely with Lithuanian officials not to declare their independence and has been jeered _ to his face _ by protestors comparing him to Nicolae Ceausescu, the Stalinist dictator of Romania executed in December in the midst of a popular uprising. But perhaps most frightening in a society so wrenched by this century's calamitous events is the uncertainty of what is to come. That fear of change is at once his toughest obstacle and his best protection. ``Perestroika depends on public opinion, and that's conservative,'' the president told reporters this month in a frank acknowledgement that he's been unable so far to initiate a long-awaited transition to a state-regulated market economy. The Associated Press learned that Gorbachev's key advisers were actively working on a plan to institute a Polish-style ``shock therapy:'' announcement of a virtual overnight conversion of the economic system by freeing most prices and currency controls and letting market forces revamp the economy. It is said that Poland shortened the painful transition period of high unemployment and runaway inflation by moving swiftly after the fall of the communist government there. But the Soviet plan to try something similar leaked to the press, touching off an outcry from a fearful public. Gorbachev and other top officials later denied they would attempt such a radical move. Last week, Gorbachev's advisers approved a milder reform plan _ which envisions a doubling of food prices, an 82 percent rise in energy costs and an average 43 percent rise in retail prices _ but only if the public supports it in a national referendum. The announcement of the food price hikes set off a wave of panic buying _ prompting Moscow officials to announce plans to restrict sales of many food and consumer products to cut down on hoarding. Absent public support, First Deputy Premier Yuri Maslyukov told a news conference, ``perhaps we will have to resort to round-table discussions'' to devise a plan that would be supported. He said the government was not proposing ``shock-therapy'' changes because such reforms could throw 40 million people out of work and ``would lead the country to the edge of an economic crash.'' Some Soviet citizens reacted with apathy to the announcement, others with emotion. A 65-year-old woman said, ``I have been suffering all my life.'' Another woman said the reforms would make food so expensive that ``I'll have to put my teeth away on a shelf.'' Gorbachev ``is in a tough position'' as head of the Communist Party, said Vyacheslav Shostakovsky, rector of the Higher Party School in Moscow. ``In the party, everyone _ from the right wing, from the left wing _ is criticizing him.'' But Shostakovsky, a leading member of the Democratic Platform group that is pushing within the party for faster reform, added that as president, Gorbachev retains the support of a broad centrist element in the country, despite the sharp criticism of him from the more radical wings of his own party. A peasant by birth and a product of the Communist system, Gorbachev has demonstrated repeatedly he is quite capable of taking one position based on traditional ideology, then abandoning it in the face of popular discontent. He did that in being converted to legalization of private ownership of factories, the ``means of production'' classical Marxists insisted were tools of exploitation unless held by the state. It sometimes even appears he has helped fuel the public's demand for change. After stubbornly resisting calls for a multiparty system, he accepted the idea, then gave at least tacit support to a huge demonstration through downtown Moscow to increase pressure on the party leadership to go along. While calling constantly for perestroika, or economic restructuring, Gorbachev often defines the debate with radicals on both sides opposed to him. He thus makes adoption of his reform proposal appear to be the centrist position. Through adroit political maneuver, Gorbachev now sits comfortably atop both the party and the government. His adversaries on the right, led by Yegor K. Ligachev, a spokesman for doctrinaire communism, no longer hold positions of power. His most vocal critic on the left, Communist maverick Boris N. Yeltsin, is waging a campaign for the presidency of the Russian republic, which would give him a new soapbox but little administrative authority over the vast territory that forms the largest of the union's 15 constituent republics. After giving in to popular demands that the Communist Party surrender its monopoly, Gorbachev led a drive this spring to legalize competing parties and simultaneously establish a strong presidency, a post he then handily won for himself in a clear demonstration of political clout. As the party inevitably loses its command over daily life, Gorbachev can continue to rule from his new power base at the top of the government. The president and his supporters are fond of saying there is no alternative to perestroika. For now, at least, the same might be said of perestroika's champion. ``The country can't do without Gorbachev now,'' said Lidya Sharlai, who raises pigs on a collective farm outside Moscow. ``In a few years, perhaps. But right now, there is no one else.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Voices Memorial Day Hopes for Peace
With AM-Summit-Bush Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush joined in the singing of ``Let There Be Peace on Earth'' at a Memorial Day service after church Sunday and voiced hope that this week's summit will bring that goal closer. Bush and his wife, Barbara, worshipped with 150 others at the First Congregational Church and afterwards joined parishioners in praying for peace at an outdoor monument to a local son, Terry Drown, killed in Vietnam in 1969. Bush was relaxing this weekend at his oceanfront home here as he prepares to welcome Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the White House on Thursday. Asked if he had a message to the nation on this weekend when America's war dead are remembered, the president said, ``Simply respect for those that gave their lives'' and ``recognition that ... the world's getting smaller.'' ``I think everybody, regardless of their faith and background, aspires to see a world of peace. ... That's what this little service is about and certainly that's what this summit coming up with Gorbachev is about,'' he said. Inside the spare but striking white clapboard church, the Rev. Patricia Adams spoke of the changes Bush alluded to. ``Our world is getting smaller every year,'' said the minister. ``We have begun to learn that we can live together despite our differences. We don't have to be clones. Different ideologies, different ideas, different dreams can co-exist quite happily.'' The Bushes, who are Episcopalians, have attended the Congregational church before, usually during visits here in the spring, winter or fall. The Episcopal church, St. Ann's, has not yet opened for the summer. Every pew was packed on a brilliant, sunny morning, and two fans on the 18-foot-high ceiling did little to keep the room from becoming warm. After weeks of rain, the coastal area has basked in three bright days since Bush arrived Friday. The minister called it ``the first official weekend of summer'' and offered a word of welcome to ``the Washington branch of our family.'' Bush stood to introduce Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner and a few others in his party. When the minister solicited prayers for the sick, Bush's son, Marvin, mentioned Lee Atwater, the ailing Republican party chairman. A massive mahogany organ with pipes painted gold stretched almost to the ceiling at the front of the church. The six-member choir sang hymns and patriotic airs. The entire congregation marched outside to the strains of ``O Beautiful for Spacious Skies'' to the monument across the street. Marshall Bush, 3, sat at her grandparents' feet beside the granite marker, dangling her foot skyward for Mrs. Bush to tie a shoe during the singing of ``Let There Be Peace on Earth.'' Then Bush shook hands all around and headed for his limousine, telling the minister, ``I think we'll push on and clear the roadway.''
