DOC.TEXT: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. (AP) _ Chevy Chase has come a long way since his pratfall days at ``Saturday Night Live'' _ he's received an honorary degree from his alma mater and given a commencement address. Chase, a 1968 graduate of Bard College, was honored Saturday at the 700-student college 90 miles north of New York City. Chase recalled that he appeared in his first movie at Bard, ``and believe it or not, it began with me pratfalling over a suitcase.'' He gave some parting words of tongue-in-cheek wisdom to the Class of 1990: ``Avoid fatty foods. Avoid smoking, drugs, Bensonhurst, the Gaza Strip, bungi jumping, humorless people, bad music, fashion, weight training and hair care products. ``Oh, and one more thing,'' Chase added. ``Never tell the truth. Embellish, patronize, pander, use hyperbole, braggadocio, mollify, but never actually tell the truth. ... Your job is to act. Keep the dream alive. Also, never call me.''

Priscilla Presley has put on the market her country French-style house in this southern California retreat northwest of Los Angeles. Asking price: $2.6 million. The house, on a wooded 2-acre plot, was built in 1964 in Montecito's ``Golden Quadrangle,'' one of the community's most exclusive neighborhoods. It has three bedrooms and three baths in about 2,600 square feet and a barn has been converted into a guest cottage. Ms. Presley bought the property in 1981, eight years after her divorce from Elvis Presley and four years after his death, but has rarely spent time there, said Linda Fareed, who has the listing through Alexander Velto Real Estate. ``She's been so busy on `Dallas' and doing other things,'' said Ms. Fareed. Besides launching her own perfume line in March and serving as co-executive producer of the now canceled ``Elvis'' series on ABC-TV, she starred as Jenna Wade during the 1987-88 season of television's ``Dallas.''

White House Chief of Staff John Sununu has received a commitment to education award and seven students won scholarships in honor of Christa C. McAuliffe, the teacher who died on the space shuttle Challenger. Sununu was given the ``I Touched the Future'' award Saturday for his contributions and commitment to education in society, said Paul S. Weller, president of Framingham State College. Weller also gave Sununu the Christa Corrigan McAuliffe medallion at a dinner arranged to raise money for a fund named after the late schoolteacher. McAuliffe and six astronauts died Jan. 28, 1986, when Challenger exploded shortly after liftoff. McAuliffe was chosen in a national search among teachers to become the first public citizen to travel into space. The McAuliffe scholarships arte for students attending or wishing to attend Framingham State, a small college about 20 miles west of Boston. Sununu, the former governor of McAuliffe's home state of New Hampshire, said politicians and parents need to stop focusing on how a school looks or its condition, and concentrate on whether children are being taught. ``The intangibles are the critical aspects of the changing needs of education,'' he said. ``Teaching is not only the most noble, but the most critical (career) for this nation.''

Actress Jill St. John and actor Robert Wagner have been married after a lengthy relationship. Miss St. John, whose films include ``Diamonds are Forever,'' was previously married and divorced three times. Wagner was married twice to the late actress Natalie Wood. On Nov. 29, 1981, Miss Wood accidentally slipped from the couple's yacht and drowned off Santa Catalina Island at the age of 43. Wagner, 60, and Miss St. John, 49, have been together for eight years, said publicist Alan Nierob. They were married Saturday in a private ceremony at Wagner's home. Katherine Wagner, 26, Wagner's daughter from his marriage to Marian Marshall, served as maid-of-honor. Natasha Gregson, 19, Miss Wood's daughter from her marriage to Richard Gregson, and Courtney Brooke Wagner, 16, daughter of Miss Wood and Wagner, were bridesmaids. Also attending were Wagner's mother and sister and Miss St. John's mother, Nierob said.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Reiterates U.S. Support of U.N. Investigation in West Bank
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Sunday the United States still supports having the United Nations investigate the treatment of Palestinians in Israel's occupied territories. Baker said the United States supports an investigation conducted in the West Bank and Gaza at the behest of the U.N. secretary-general. But he drew a distinction between a mission dispatched by the secretary-general and a mission sent by the U.N. Security Council. ``I hope that the Arab leadership and I hope that the government of Israel will both support the idea of sending an investigative mission from the secretary-general to the territories and report back,'' he said. ``That is something the United States will support, and I hope that we can see the parties come together on that,'' Baker said. Baker's comments on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation'' program came the day after the United States blocked an attempt by the Security Council to send a mission to the occupied territories. Arab leaders were angered by the U.S. move at the Security Council meeting in Geneva, Switzerland, and they claimed Baker had reneged on a promise. The United States objected to the investigative mission after Israel refused to accept any team sent by the Security Council. Baker said Arabs ``must have misunderstood'' what they thought was his earlier backing of a Security Council investigative team. Arab countries this week called for U.N. protection of Palestinians living in the occupied territories. At least 15 Palestinians have been killed in clashes with Israeli defense forces in the past week. On Saturday, kidnappers holding two American hostages in Lebanon blamed the United States for the massacre of seven Palestinian workers in Israel on May 20. Israeli officials have said the accused gunman, a former soldier, apparently was deranged. In a statement issued Saturday in Beirut, the Organization of Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, vowed to make the United States and Israel ``pay the price'' for the killings. However, the group did not threaten hostages Jesse Turner and Allan Steen. Meantime, Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir reiterated his opposition to any U.N. peace-keeping forces or other observers in the occupied territories. ``I don't think we need peace-keeping forces for having peace,'' he said. ``Our experience is that such forces are not bringing peace. They are causing tensions and not peace. ``We don't need foreign military men to police the country, the area. We need peaceful talks. That's all.''

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Wants Complete Search of Seized Fishing Boat
DOC.TEXT: Crews worked Sunday to unload fuel tanks on a 90-foot fishing boat seized in a drug raid off the coast so the boat could be searched for hidden compartments, the Coast Guard said. No contraband was immediately found on the boat, which was seized Saturday off Half Moon Bay and towed to San Francisco after San Mateo County sheriff's deputies spotted a suspected drug-smuggling operation along the coast, according to a Coast Guard statement. Twelve men _ seven on shore and five aboard the vessel _ were arrested, and federal and state officials combed a 20-mile stretch of coastline for drugs they suspect were dumped from the trawler. Five pounds of marijuana was seized on shore near Pescadero, about 30 miles south of San Francisco, said sheriff's Sgt. Mike Peck. The arrests and seizure came after sheriff's deputies spotted several people on state Highway 1 near the coast throwing something from a bridge, authorities said. An inflatable boat was found nearby. Three of the 12 are being held on investigation of drug charges, and the others were under investigation by federal immigration authorities, the sheriff's department said. Those arrested were believed to be foreign nationals, but their nationality was not immediately known, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Scandinavian Star Survivors, Families Make Memorial Voyage
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people dropped flowers into the North Sea over the weekend during a solemn memorial for the 158 people who died in a ferry fire last month that probably was set by an arsonist. The Scandinavian Star was engulfed in flames midway on its overnight run from Oslo, Norway to Frederikshavn, Denmark. Most of the victims were Norwegians. About 300 people, including survivors and relatives of people who died in the disaster, lined the rail of this ship during a sunset memorial service on Saturday. The two-day memorial voyage was arranged by a survivors' support group, and clergymen and psychologists helped comfort those mourning the people who died aboard the Scandinavian Star ferry when a fire raced through it on April 7. ``I have been here before. A month and half ago when, like all of us in our own ways, I was marked for life,'' said survivor Grete Holen. As the King of Scandinavia cut its motors and stopped in the North Sea where the disaster occurred, she said: ``We are bound together by a meaningless tragedy. All of us have had a piece of us ripped out forever.'' An American entertainer, Ruth E. Rome, 27, of East Lansing, Mich., was among the casualties. Police believe the fire was set. A Dane with a history of mental disorders and pyromania died in the inferno, leading police to theorize that he may have been the arsonist. The investigation is continuing. ``I think of all the people who died so needlessly. I think of the seconds and millimeters we were from dying,'' said Tore Netteland, as the car and passenger ferry sailed the route of the Scandinavian Star. Some returned to the site of the tragedy to help cope with grief or fear. Others said they came to say farewell. Ms. Holen expressed anger about safety rules that allowed the Scandinavian Star to sail. The ferry, registered under a flag of convenience, was unprepared to handle a disaster, investigators say. A marine inquiry heard a catalog of safety omissions and blunders that may have helped the fire spread and hinder rescue operations. The Norwegian captain was found to have abandoned the ship while passengers remained alive on board. ``Our private sorrow is one thing. The public side of this is that we want the world to know that there is a lesson in this tragedy,'' Ms. Holen said, calling for tougher safety regulations. A commission of representatives from Norway, Denmark and Sweden ordered regulations tightened for ferry traffic in Scandinavian waters.

DOC.HEAD: Violence in Sindh Province Leaves More Than 80 Dead, 275 Hurt
DOC.TEXT: Pakistan's troubled Sindh province exploded in violence Sunday that left at least 82 people dead and more than 275 hurt in two cities, authorities and witnesses said. In Hyderabad, in southern Sindh, security forces on Sunday shot and killed 60 people and wounded more than 200 who defied a 13-day-old curfew imposed to curb ethnic violence, police and witnesses said. In the province's capital, Karachi, 150 miles to the south, at least 22 people were killed and 75 others wounded in sniper attacks Sunday, officials said. Authorities clamped curfews on three of the most violent districts. Much of the province has been hit in recent years by a wave of kidnappings, assassinations and sniper attacks that have left more than 2,000 people dead. The violence in Hyderabad broke out Sunday after Moslem leaders used loudspeakers at neighborhood mosques to call residents into the streets. Hundreds of people, many clutching the Moslem holy book, the Koran, poured out of their homes, police and witnesses said. The shooting set off gun battles between residents and troops patrolling the city, police and witnesses said, and the army moved in to restore order. Opposition politicians in Parliament demanded the dismissal of provincial government officials and called for a state of emergency to be declared in Sindh, Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's home province. In the past two weeks, gun battles have brought life to a standstill for Hyderabad's 3 million residents. The curfew violators in Hyderabad on Sunday were demanding restoration of water and power, and trying to get food. Security forces warned people to go back inside, and opened fire when the warnings were ignored, witnesses said. Ambulances rushed victims to a nearby hospital, but doctors said they could not treat them all. As word of the shooting spread, witnesses said, furious residents began taking potshots at paramilitary troops, riot police and rangers. ``People were trying to break through police barricades and shooting from their rooftops,'' said one witness, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The situation got totally out of control.'' After five hours, witnesses said, the army moved in. Earlier Sunday in Karachi, Pakistan's largest city, snipers launched a series of attacks beginning early in the morning, firing at pedestrians and vehicles. Authorities refused to say who might be responsible. Most shops and businesses closed when the shooting started, they said. No one has claimed responsibility, but police frequently blame violence on a militant faction of the Mohajir Qami Movement, or MQM, a small political party representing descendants of Moslem Indians who immigrated to Pakistan during the 1947 partition of the subcontinent. The group is demanding recognition as Pakistan's fifth nationality, along with the Punjabis, Pathans, Sindhis and Baluch. Thousands of troops swept across Sindh last week and arrested more than 800 people, including members of the MQM and Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party. The MQM once backed Ms. Bhutto's government but withdrew its support in November, forcing a no-confidence vote the prime minister narrowly survived. Many residents believe the problem in Sindh is beyond the government's control. Authorities have never made arrests in a massacre on Sept. 30, 1988 that left at least 300 dead in Hyderabad. Ms. Bhutto acknowledged that the provincial government has not done enough to curb the escalating violence and lawlessness. But she accused neighboring India of stirring up trouble in Sindh and the eastern province of Punjab. New Delhi denies those allegations and blames Pakistan for violent separatist movements in Indian Punjab and Jammu-Kashmir, India's only Moslem majority state. Pakistan denies the charges.

DOC.HEAD: Detectives Again Investigating Serial Slayings in Northwest
DOC.TEXT: In scenes grimly reminiscent of the nation's largest unsolved serial murder case, police are investigating the deaths of three prostitutes dumped near the Spokane River. Similarities exist between this case and the unsolved Green River slayings that stopped six years ago in the Seattle area, but investigators doubt they're linked. Still, police in Spokane are handling the latest case as the work of a serial killer. It comes as no surprise to seasoned investigators that another serial killer may be active in the Pacific Northwest. ``The Northwest is a particularly attractive area for a serial killer to traverse,'' said Capt. T. Michael Nault, head of a unit that includes the Green River Task Force based in Seattle, 300 miles west of Spokane. ``That is primarily because of the region's perceived remoteness, its lesser per capita law enforcement and even its reputation for a more laid-back law enforcement.'' A detective from the Green River unit will meet soon with Spokane investigators to point out potential pitfalls, said Lt. Jim Hill, head of major crimes investigations for Spokane police. Nault, Hill and others see no apparent links between the slayings of the three women in Spokane and the Green River case. But as Nault put it: ``It's reckless to say there is no possibility.'' Police are investigating eight sets of serial killings on the West Coast, Nault said. The Green River serial killer is blamed in the deaths and disappearances of as many as 49 women in the Pacific Northwest between mid-1982 and early 1984, many of them prostitutes. The first Spokane River victim turned up in February and the most recent earlier this month. All three women, who had police records for soliciting, were shot several times with a small caliber weapon before their naked or semi-nude bodies were dumped, police said. ``We were a little better off than the Green River investigation because we had (the slayings) associated with a serial crime right away,'' Hill said. ``We have a computer program that has been in place since the second incident. It's a matter of making sure we don't repeat someone else's errors.'' Police in King County, where many of the Green River victims were found, were criticized for not recognizing soon enough that a serial killer was loose. Spokane investigators began looking into a possible serial crime after the second body, that of Nickie Lowe, 34, was found March 25. By the time the body of the third victim, Kathleen A. Brisbois, 38, was found May 15, police had met with the Spokane County Sheriff's Department, which contributed a detective to the investigation. The body of the first woman, 26-year-old Yolanda Sapp, was found on a riverbank Feb. 22. Except for the first five bodies found in or near the Green River in August 1982, police found only skeletal remains, making clues harder to find in that case. The Spokane River remains were found within days or hours of death, which could yield better clues. ``The rule of thumb is, the sooner you get it, the more likely you are to resolve it,'' said Hill. ``That's true whether it's a homicide or a robbery or burglary.''

DOC.HEAD: Veterans of Dunkirk Honor Slain Comrades
DOC.TEXT: With prayers, hymns and tears, thousands of veterans of the Dunkirk evacuation assembled on a once-bloody beachfront Sunday to honor comrades killed 50 years ago in one of World War II's most crucial operations. The veterans, most British and many supporting themselves with canes or umbrellas, watched as a Royal Navy Helicopter dropped a wreath of poppies over a circle of dozens of the ships that helped rescue trapped Allied troops in 1940. The former soldiers were deployed in ranks under their regimental standards, and a chorus of ``God Save the Queen'' echoed over the waves. At least 15,000 people, including relatives and onlookers, were present. The veterans marched or rode to the beach after a ceremony in the city center, rebuilt from near destruction in the Nazi bombardment that chased the Allied soldiers to the seaside as France fell to Germany. ``Some of us have been here before,'' Lord Donald Kaberry, president of the Dunkirk Veterans Association, told the assembled French, Belgian, Dutch, Australian and British veterans. ``We were here 50 years ago, when we crossed the beaches and went back to the United Kingdom to regroup, fight again and win,'' said Kaberry, 82. He was an acting major in the British Expeditionary Force when he was evacuated with 338,000 other Allied troops in what became known as ``the Miracle of Dunkirk.'' About 6,000 British veterans and their relatives descended on the port city in far northern France for weekend celebrations commemorating Operation Dynamo. It began when a ragtag fleet of 800 naval vessels, barges, fishing boats and pleasure craft rallied to Winston Churchill's call to save the Allied armies from the encircling Wehrmacht. On Thursday, seventy-three ships, many involved in the operation, braved choppy Channel waters to cross from Dover to Dunkirk and join the commemorations. Most were able to muster in a circle offshore Sunday. Dignitaries on hand included Dunkirk Mayor Michel Delabarre, who is France's transport minister, and British Transport Secretary Cecil Parkinson. For the veterans, the return to Dunkirk was a time to reflect on the war, their comrades who died and their own luck in having survived. William Bannister, then a 20-year-old sapper in the King's Own Royal Regiment, had gone without food for two days when he finally made it aboard the British destroyer HMS Esk and curled up under a gun turret to sleep. Moments later, the ship was attacked by German dive bombers. ``Fortunately they were all near misses. I just went to sleep, even though that gun was going off all the while. It didn't wake me up. I didn't move until I got back to Dover.'' Many of the survivors, such as 71-year-old former Sgt. James Wright, went on to fight in North Africa, Italy and Normandy. Wright recalled Dunkirk in May 1940 as a crushed city _ pounded to rubble by German bombers and artillery, littered with burning vehicles, bodies of thousands of civilians and soldiers dotting the beaches and streets. ``The first time I was here, it was in ruins, all burning,'' he said, gazing at the modern brick buildings, decked with French and British flags, that now form the city center. English fisherman George Osborne, 76, said he makes an annual trip to Dunkirk. Injured in a shipboard accident, he stayed behind when his two brothers and three cousins crossed the Channel in their fishing boat toward the besieged beaches. A German mine blew them to pieces. ``It doesn't seem like 50 years ago,'' he said, choking back tears. ``It seems like yesterday. When I come back here, I feel like I'm with them again.''

DOC.HEAD: Mom Stakes Out Bus Stop, Police Charge Man With Kidnap Attempt
DOC.TEXT: A woman police call a ``super mom'' staked out her 10-year-old daughter's bus stop with a camera after the girl complained of being repeatedly approached by a stranger. Officers credit the mother with helping catch an ex-convict who has been charged with assault with intent to commit kidnapping. David Bruce Siebers, released last year after serving nine years of a 10-to 21-year term on several charges, including rape, was arrested Thursday and arraigned Friday. The Kent County Sheriff's Department would not release the woman's name Sunday. She talked with the Grand Rapids Press on Friday on condition of anonymity. The woman told police her daughter was approached three times by a man at her bus stop. Officers watched the bus stop for a few days before giving up. After that, the woman took over, arming herself with binoculars and a camera with a zoom lens and managing to get a picture when a suspect reappeared Thursday. ``What a super mom. I can't praise her enough,'' said police Sgt. Kenneth Kleinheksel. ``Without her, this guy could have done a lot of harm.'' The woman said she happened to be watching her daughter May 16 when a man in a car drove up to her. ``I went right out there to ask who that person was and she said, `He told me to get in the car. He'd drive me to school. He showed me money, Mom. A bunch of it,''' she told the newspaper. ``When she said this was the third time he's done this, I was flabbergasted.'' ``She said, `He's stupid to think I'd fall for something like that.' I don't think it occurred to her how dangerous it was until she saw my reaction,'' the woman said. Police put unmarked surveillance cars at the bus stop for a few days, but when that ended, the mother armed herself with binoculars and a camera with a zoom lens. She said she spotted the car near her daughter on Thursday. ``I watched him pull up and was ready to tear off after him. She (the girl) turned and looked at him and ran for the house. It seemed like it took forever for her to run for safety, but it was probably really less than a second,'' said the mother. ``He took off, and I took off after him at about 70, 75 miles an hour.'' The mother recorded the man's license plate and snapped a blurry picture of the car as she followed him. That led to Siebers' arrest. If convicted, Siebers could face up to 20 years in prison. Bond was set at $25,000 but Siebers was ordered held because of possible violation of his parole. In 1980, a plea bargain agreement allowed Siebers to plead guilty but mentally ill to the August 1979 gunpoint rape of a store clerk. He also pleaded guilty to armed robbery and possession of a firearm during the commission of a felony, stemming from a November 1979 restaurant robbery. Two other rape charges and three other armed robbery charges were dropped as part of the deal. In 1984, a judge reduced his sentence because of his status as a model prisoner.

DOC.HEAD: Colombians Vote in Presidential Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 7th graf pvs, `Colombians also,' to UPDATE with projection on approval of constitutional assembly; pick up 8th graf pvs, `Proponents of...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BOG1
DOC.TEXT: Millions of people ignored terrorist threats and voted Sunday in a presidential election that will determine the course of the nation's war against the powerful drug cartels and their hired killers. Under the watchful eye of army sharpshooters, women with babies in their arms joined other Colombians in choosing among 12 candidates who survived a campaign in which three of their rivals were shot and killed. Guerrilla groups also have been blamed for campaign attacks, and there was scattered rebel violence in remote villages Saturday night and before dawn Sunday. Four policemen were reported wounded and seven were missing in the attacks, according to radio reports. The main issue that divided the four top candidates was whether to continue the government's harsh crackdown on drug traffickers and its policy of extraditing top dealers to the United States for prosecution. Cesar Gaviria, 43, the candidate of the governing Liberal Party, who has pledged to continue the crackdown, led all independent polls and was expected to easily win the election. The candidate with the most votes wins, even if he fails to garner more than 50 percent of the ballots. Colombians also voted on whether to call a national assembly to make changes in Colombia's 104-year-old constitution. The new president would decide which political parties and other groups should appoint the assembly, which would act independently of the nation's standing, elected Congress. The radio network Caracol said Sunday afternoon that based on a poll, it was projecting approval of the constitutional assembly by more than 90 percent of the voters. Proponents of constitutional reform say changes are needed to break the upper class's grip on this country. Proposed changes would strengthen the judicial system, emphasize land reform and increase checks and balances in the government. Colombia's president now has wide powers that easily allow him to sidestep Congress and the Supreme Court. The polls opened at 8 a.m. and preliminary results were expected an hour or so after polls closed at 5 p.m. (6 p.m. EDT). More than 13 million people were eligible to vote, but turnout figures were not immediately available. The vote was suspended in four villages because of guerrilla incursions, government and army officials were quoted as telling the national radio networks RCN and Caracol. The rebels also ambushed police patrols near three more villages, the reports said. As the polls opened in the capital, Bogota Mayor Andres Pastrana declared one minute of silence for the three assassinated presidential candidates. A police bugler played taps during the ceremony at the huge Bolivar Plaza, causing many in the crowd of hundreds to weep openly. Besides the three presidential candidates, 262 policemen, 93 soldiers, three judges, 15 news media employees and about 1,700 other people have been slain in the past nine months. Bombs have exploded at schools, churches and stores. One bomb killed 107 people on a Colombian jetliner. In the two weeks leading up to Sunday's balloting, nine bombs exploded in four Colombian cities, killing 37 people and wounding more than 320. Few of the crimes have been solved, but suspicion for most of the killings has fallen on drug traffickers, who have private armies and billions of dollars in cocaine profits at their disposal, and who hoped to disrupt the election. President Virgilio Barco, who is prohibited from seeking a second consecutive four-year term, voted along with his wife in the plaza. Several hours earlier, he went on national television to appeal to voters to show courage and come out to vote. ``My countrymen, never before has it been so clear that the future of Colombia is in your hands. All of us must vote,'' he said. ``To vote is to support democracy, to reject violence and to defend the rights that the terrorists want to snatch from us.'' ``I do not have the slightest doubt that both the terrorist acts aimed at taking the lives of presidential candidates as well as those committed against other compatriots have been carried out to intimidate the popular will.'' An armed force of 232,000 men was put on alert several days before the election. Troops were seen throughout the capital of 6 million people. Police and army sharpshooters were crouched on the roofs of buildings near many voting booths early Sunday. The four main candidates were Gaviria, Rodrigo Lloreda, 48; Alvaro Gomez, 71, and Antonio Navarro, 41. Gaviria became the Liberal Party candidate after Luis Carlos Galan assassination by drug traffickers on Aug. 18. His killing prompted the government to declare war on the drug cartels. Lloreda, a former foreign minister, has said he would end extradition of trafficking suspects to the United States. Lloreda represents the Conservative Party, the country's second-largest party. Gomez broke from the Conservative Party to run as an independent. He, too, has suggested that he would end extraditions. He wants cocaine legalized in the United States and other countries, saying this would deprive the traffickers of profits they use to terrorize Colombia and undermine its democracy. Navarro was one of the leaders the April 19 Movement guerrilla group, known as the M-19. The rebel group disbanded earlier this year in exchange for pardons and the right to form a political party. Navarro stepped in when the party's first presidential candidate, Carlos Pizarro, was assassinated on April 26 in a killing blamed on drug traffickers. Navarro favors continuing the government's crackdown. The third presidential candidate assassinated was Bernardo Jaramillo of the Patriotic Union Party. He was slain March 22. The party, its ranks decimated by right-wing death squads, withdrew from the election. The police said drug traffickers killed Jaramillo.

DOC.HEAD: Manhattan Project Scientist Emil Konopinski Dead At 78
DOC.TEXT: Emil J. Konopinski, who helped design the atomic bomb, died Saturday at Bloomington Hospital after a long illness at age 78. The exact cause of death was not given. Konopinski, a physics professor emeritus at Indiana University, initially worked on the construction of the first nuclear fission reactor with Enrico Fermi at the University of Chicago. He went to the Los Alamos National Laboratory during World War II with J. Robert Oppenheimer and Edward Teller to set up the research group that developed the first atomic bomb. Konopinski helped design the bomb before the needed uranium and plutonium were available. He also did safety calculations for the plants where the bombs would be manufactured. He proved theoretically that a thermonuclear explosion would not ignite the atmosphere or the oceans and destroy the Earth. The scientists could not perform test explosions without this information. From 1946 to 1968 he served as a consultant to the Atomic Energy Commission. He wrote the book, ``The Theory of Beta Radioactivity.'' Survivors include a brother, Eugene W. Konrad, and a sister, Marian Hansen.

DOC.HEAD: Six Die in Clashes Between Opposition Group, Security Forces
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and 5th graf, `The clash...' to clarify location and that city in English-speaking area; pickup 6th graf, `President Paul...'
DOC.TEXT: A clash between supporters of a fledgling opposition party and security forces left six demonstrators dead and an unspecified number of police injured in a city northwest of here, state-run radio said Sunday. Cameroon is the latest of France's former African colonies where an opposition movement has called on an authoritarian government to make political reforms. The radio said demonstrators were trampled to death in Saturday's clash, but witnesses said they were shot by police. The radio also claimed the demonstrators stoned and clubbed unarmed police, burned police vehicles and set up barricades before reinforcements arrived to subdue the protesters. The clash came after supporters of the newly formed Democratic Social Front assembled in Bamenda, in an English-speaking area 36 miles east of the Nigerian frontier. Authorities had warned the group not to try to hold political meetings. President Paul Biya, who has ruled since November 1982, has refused to allow any opposition parties to organize. Although the country's constitution allows such parties, Biya's Cameroon Democratic People's Movement is the only legal party. In April, a lawyer and 10 other people were convicted of subversion after trying to organize an opposition party. Soldiers prevented the public from watching the rial, and one of the defense lawyers was shot dead at a roadblock on the day the convictions were handed down. The Cameroon Bar Association has called on the government to tolerate opposition, but has been warned that it should remain out of politics. The Democratic Social Front was first formed three months ago by a Bamenda publisher, John Frundi. He filed papers to create his party with government authorities and was told it would take two months to examine them. Two weeks ago, having received no reply, he said he was going ahead with organization of the party. Cameroon gained independence from France in 1960 but the former British Cameroons did not become part of the country until 1961. Part of it was incorporated into Nigeria and a strip along the eastern Nigerian border was made part of Cameroon.

DOC.HEAD: White Army Veterans, ANC Guerrillas Bury the Hatchet
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress guerrilla commanders and veteran officers of the white-led South African army ended an unprecedented conference Sunday pledging to work for peace. In a joint statement released in the Zambian capital after five days of talks, the two sides declared there should be a ``mutually binding cessation of hostilities'' as soon as possible. The conference, convened to discuss the present and future role of the security forces, went ahead without the blessing of South African Defense Minister Magnus Malan. But the 48 current and former military officers who attended said they would make recommendations privately to the government on their return home. The participants said they envisioned a cease-fire agreement under which the ANC military wing would halt guerrilla attacks and sabotage, while the South African army would remove troops from black townships and halt search-and-kill operations. Before departing for home late Sunday, the officers said they had developed friendships with the guerrillas. One Cuban-trained ANC fighter said he was impressed with the frankness of the talks and the warm atmosphere. ``We've always told ourselves that if we ever came across an SADF man anywhere it would be a question of who was faster,'' said the man, who identified himself only as Duncan. He referred to the South African Defense Force. Lusaka was chosen as the location for the conference because it is close to South Africa and is home to the external headquarters of the ANC, the largest movement fighting to end South Africa's apartheid policies. The Lusaka meeting was the latest example of easing hostilities between South Africa's white minority, which controls political and economic power, and the 28 million voteless black majority. The ANC and other anti-apartheid movements were legalized in February. ANC leader Nelson Mandela was also freed from 27 years' imprisonment for anti-government activities. Earlier this month both Mandela and President F.W. de Klerk, architect of the reforms, began talks on the political future of South Africa. Military crackdowns on activists in black townships postponed the first planned meeting. In Lusaka, the two sides agreed that once progress has been made in political discussions, ANC guerrillas should be permitted to return to South Africa and integrated into the existing army or demobilized. A new restructured army of conventional troops and former guerrillas should be non-partisan, accountable to Parliament and recruited and promoted on the basis of merit alone, their joint statement said. ``We began a process over the last few days of moving forward together,'' ANC foreign affairs chief Thabo Mbeki said. ``We have an obligation to our people to sustain that process.''

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Leader Links Freeing British Hostages to Rushdie
DOC.TEXT: A Shiite Moslem leader said Sunday at least one of four British hostages in Lebanon could be released if British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher deports writer Salman Rushdie for allegedly defaming Islam. Hussein Musawi also said the May 19 massacre of seven Palestinian laborers by an Israeli gunman will hurt efforts to free the six American hostages in Lebanon. ``I believe and hope that some of the British hostages could be freed if Margaret Thatcher deported Salman Rushdie from England,'' Musawi said. Rushdie, an Indian-born naturalized Briton, was sentenced to death by Iran's revolutionary leader, the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, in February 1989 for allegedly blaspheming Islam in his novel, ``The Satanic Verses.'' ``She doesn't have to hand him over to us or send him to Iran or Syria,'' he said. ``It would be enough if she gave us proof that he has left the country. ``She can send him anywhere she wants,'' Musawi said from his headquarters in the Bekaa Valley town of Baalbek in east Lebanon. The Britons and Americans are among 16 Westerners missing in Lebanon. Most are held by pro-Iranian Shiite factions. Longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for the Associated Press. He was kidnapped on March 16, 1985. Iran severed relations with Britain in February 1989 after Britain accused the Iranians of terrorism and protested Khomeini's death threat. Rushdie has been in hiding under guard ever since. Iran and Syria helped obtain the release last month of American hostages Robert Polhill and Frank Reed as ``goodwill gestures.'' But the Iranians have said no more Americans will be freed until Washington makes a reciprocal gesture. President Bush has refused, citing his policy of not negotiating with terrorists and those who support them. Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani on Sunday reiterated Iran's accusation that the West had made no move to obtain the release of ``Iranian, Lebanese and Palestinian hostages'' to reciprocate for the release of American hostages. Rafsanjani referred to Palestinians and Lebanese Shiite Moslems held by Israel and their Christian allies in southern Lebanon, and four Iranians kidnapped and missing in the Christian enclave in Lebanon in 1982. ``I believe that the British, unlike the Americans, are now behaving in a positive manner that may encourage the hostage-holders to free a British hostage as a goodwill gesture,'' Musawi said. Musawi heads Islamic Amal, a pro-Syrian faction within the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, believed the parent movement for the extremists holding Westerners. He is also reputed mentor of Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, a Shiite faction that holds American educators Jesse Turner and Alann Steen. Musawi was believed to have been instrumental in securing the release of Polhill April 22. But he urged kidnappers not to free Reed after the U.S. Congress endorsed a united Jerusalem as Israel's capital two days later. Musawi made his remarks as radical Iranian newspapers in Tehran said that any British effort to restore relations with Tehran were pointless so long as Mrs. Thatcher's government defends Rushdie. ``London's efforts are doomed if they are directed to secure Salman Rushdie's life,'' the Jomhuri Islami daily said in an editorial. The British captives are Anglican Church envoy Terry Waite, who disappeared Jan. 20, 1987; journalist John McCarthy, kidnapped April 17, 1986; ex-Royal Air Force pilot Jack Mann, kidnapped May 12, 1989, and writer Alec Collett, kidnapped March 25, 1985. Musawi's remarks came a day after the pro-Iranian Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine said it would make the United States and Israel ``pay the price'' for the killing the unarmed Palestinians by a former Israeli soldier. ``This massacre will have a negative effect on the issue of the American hostages,'' Musawi said. ``Israelis cannot do anything without American backing. This is how things are linked in the minds and thoughts of our people,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Six Killed in Boston Fire
DOC.TEXT: A fire possibly started by a cigarette killed all five members of a young family and a visitor at their home Sunday in the deadliest blaze in Boston in 18 years, officials said. Firefighters were on the scene about three minutes after the fire was reported in the wooden duplex, but flames spread too fast for the occupants to be saved, said Fire Commissioner Leo Stapleton. ``These were old wooden buildings, about 100 years old, so the fire spread very quickly,'' he said. ``It raced right up the stairs into the bedrooms.'' Stapleton said he suspected a cigarette left in an overstuffed chair might have sparked the blaze. ``We know one of the male occupants had been smoking earlier in the evening,'' Stapleton said. ``We think right now the cause was careless smoking.'' The fire leaped to an adjoining building and crossed an alley to a third building, but no other injuries were reported, Stapleton said. It was the worst blaze in the city since 1972, when nine firefighters died battling a fire at the Hotel Vendome, Stapleton said. Fire officials did not immediately identify the victims but said they were a couple, both in their 20s, and their three young daughters. A man believed to be a friend of the family also died, officials said. A woman believed to be the young mother's sister escaped by climbing out a window and into an adjoining building.

DOC.HEAD: Veterans Walk to Remember POWs, MIAs
DOC.TEXT: Veterans and supporters took the first steps of hundred-mile walks Sunday in three states as they sought to remind the nation during the Memorial Day weekend that many soldiers have never come home. ``We're sure that we still have some prisoners in Southeast Asia. We're going to work at this thing till the day when some of them walk out of there,'' said World War II veteran Charles Walker. Four groups _ from Chicago, Peoria, Madison, Wis.; and Baldwin, Iowa _ are staging the event dubbed the ``Walk of the Warriors,'' said Mary Buttry Holub of Warrenville, who helped organize it. The marchers plan to meet Thursday in the northern Illinois city of Oregon and continue Friday to the nearby Lake LaDonna campground, where they plan to spend the weekend camping together. Before they started, organizers were unsure how many people would participate in the walk in honor of prisoners of war and those declared missing in action. A total of 2,340 American servicemen remain unaccounted for in Southeast Asia, said Tom Stack, a member of the Illinois Vietnam Veterans Leadership Program. Holub had just graduated from Lisle High School west of Chicago in 1965 when the Vietnam War began to affect her directly and ultimately change her life. In 1966, one of her best friends was killed. ``We didn't believe it would happen. We'd just graduated, and life was fun. Vietnam was so far away. It wasn't part of our lives,'' she said. Her brother joined the Marines in 1969, the same year her cousin was killed in the war. Her brother came home, but suffered from addiction to drugs, alcoholism and what veterans call ``survivor guilt,'' Holub said. But since then, she said, her brother has turned around his life, is raising a family and devotes himself to the prisoner-of-war issue _ a commitment she's also made. ``I have two boys,'' she said. ``I don't want to give up my children to a foreign country and not get them back. I have no problem letting them serve because I love my country. But we've been lied to.'' She noted that a pending House measure would amend the 1942 Missing Personnel Act to require the government to provide proof before declaring a soldier dead. Now the law allows a declaration of death after one year without proof, she said. Stack said the marchers' goal ``is to heighten that awareness so people will get involved to request of their officials, congressmen and senators that they continue to work hard to explore this issue to the `nth' degree.'' Stack, who wears a bracelet commemorating an Air Force colonel shot down over Laos on April 25, 1971, added, ``I empathize for those family members who don't know. There has to be an accounting. If there are remains, the remains should be returned. If they're alive, they should be returned.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Roll Past White House in Support of Missing in Action
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of motorcycle enthusiasts staged a ``rolling thunder'' rally Sunday past the White House and the Soviet and Laotian embassies to protest the handling of America's missing in action from the Vietnam War. ``The effort is to keep alive before the public and the media an issue the White House is trying to lay to rest,'' said Ted Sampley of Kinston, N.C., one of the organizers. National Park Police estimated that 15,000 people took part in the rally and an associated ``Rock for Freedom'' concert and demonstration held near the Lincoln and Vietnam Memorials. Thousands of cyclists gathered shortly before noon at the Pentagon before motoring past the White House along a police-approved route. Police rejected a request for a permit for the cyclists to motor en masse past the Soviet and Laotian embassies, claiming it would tie up traffic, according to the event's organizers. Nonetheless, groups of five to 20 cyclists at a time rumbled in ad hoc ``thunder alley runs'' throughout the afternoon in front of the embassies, where organizers handed out patches with skulls and crossbones to riders as they passed. ``The authorities have done everything in their power to interfere with this thing,'' said Sampley, who chairs a group called the National Steering Committee for American War Veterans. ``The State Department did not want us over at the Laotian Embassy.'' He said the embassy was targeted because Laos ``never has answered publicly'' what became of the U.S. prisoners they were holding at the end of the war. About 2,300 Americans are now listed by the government as missing in action in the Vietnam War, which also included fighting in Cambodia and Laos. The war ended in 1975 with Communist victories in all three countries. Of the missing, 537 were in Laos when last seen _ most of them in areas then under control of North Vietnamese forces, according to U.S. officials.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa: Rail Strike Could Lead to Civil War
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa told striking train workers that their walkout is propelling the country toward civil war, but the strikers rebuffed his appeal for a settlement and threatened new stoppages. The Solidarity labor union's leader also suggested that Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki might be forced to resign if the protests spread. A week of sporadic strikes has crippled freight transport to Poland's Baltic coast from the industrial south and Czechoslovakia and Hungary. The army has been called in to move essential shipments. Walesa held a three-hour meeting with the strikers, who broke off talks with the government in Warsaw a day earlier. The Solidarity labor leader, who himself rose to prominence by leading the strike at the Gdansk shipyard, begged the workers to call off the walkout. ``Please do it for Poland,'' he said. ``We don't want a civil war now, and what's going on now is leading to it.'' The new Solidarity government has refused to even discuss the strikers' pay demands. It says they could scuttle the drastic economic reforms now under way. Strikers said they will carry out a new stoppage Monday. The Solidarity railroad union urged members not to participate in the stoppage at midday Monday. The move is being spearheaded by the OPZZ union, which was formerly backed by the old Communist government. The strike committee is also calling for a work stoppage on Tuesday evening. Officials said thousands of the nation's 400,000 railroad workers were striking but could give no specific number. Transport officials have noted that it only takes a few strikers to snarl rail traffic. Walesa has charged that the strikers' legitimate grievances are being manipulated by the OPZZ union, whose chairman is a former Communist Party Politburo member. Solidarity Labor Minister Jacek Kuron says the wage demands are inflationary. ``I am willing to talk with everybody ... about everything except wages,'' he said. The strikers want to raise rail workers' pay to 110 percent of the average national wage of about $79 monthly. They are also seeking the dismissal of railroad directors installed by the former Communist government, whom they say are incompetent and hampering reforms. Walesa told the strikers the government cannot give in because ``there are others waiting in line for strikes.'' ``The government's concession ... would be an indication that if one goes on strike, one gets whatever one wants. The prime minister will resign if protests spread,'' Walesa said. Mazowiecki has repeatedly voiced sympathy Poles suffering hardship during the 5-month-old bid to create a market economy from the shattered socialist system. But the prime minister said there would be no return to the huge government subsidies for unprofitable and inefficient state-run industries, including the railroads.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Appeals for Calm in the Face of Panic Buying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for news analysis slugged AM-Soviet-Reforms
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in a hastily scheduled television address Sunday, appealed to countrymen to stay calm about plans to double food prices under a shift to a regulated market economy. ``Don't panic, comrades!'' Gorbachev said, hoping to stem a run on stores prompted by the new economic reform package announced Thursday by Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. He acknowledged that ``an anxious mood has arisen in the country'' over the economic plan. The Soviet president spoke for 45 minutes from a prepared text. He is scheduled to leave Tuesday for a summit meeting in Washington with President Bush. In addition to touching off panic buying, the reforms have also drawn criticism from such radicals as Boris N. Yeltsin who advocate a much swifter transition to a market economy. Yeltsin is running on a radical reform platform for president of the Russian federation, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics. He failed to gain a majority in the first two rounds of balloting in the Russian Congress last week, but said he will compete in the third round, scheduled for Monday. In his speech, Gorbachev said that under the new reforms, lower income people would be compensated for the price increases and those who lose their jobs would be retrained for new work. Some economists have estimated that up to 40 million people could lose their jobs as a result of the reforms, expected to drive many inefficient businesses into bankruptcy. But Gorbachev said, ``This transition to a market economy ... cannot be postponed, because negative consequences will develop. What we need now is social accord.'' He did not mention a plan for holding a public referendum on the radical five-year reform. That was discussed by Ryzhkov's deputies Yuri Maslyukov and Leonid Abalkin on Wednesday. Under Ryzhkov's reforms, bread prices would triple to about $1.09 a loaf on July 1, and other food prices would double on average on Jan 1. The average Soviet monthy salary is $279. Ryzhkov said Thursday that bread makes up 20 percent of the average Soviet diet. Under the three-phase reform plan, which carries through 1995, 60 percent of state enterprises would be sold to the public sector, and controls would be lifted on 60 percent of prices. Other prices would remain under state control, and many industries would stay in state hands, over the opposition of radical reformers. Gorbachev said the current price of bread ``does not at all correspond to the amount of labor in its production. ... People buy bread and feed it to their animals. And this at a time when we are forced to buy grain abroad.'' He said that in the United States and Canada, which sell grain to Moscow, the price of bread is four times as high as in the Soviet Union, where food prices are heavily subsidized. Panic buying continued on Sunday in Soviet stores. Shoppers jammed Gastronom No. 1 on Gorky Street, where clerks said sales were several times the normal rate. Gorbachev, without mentioning names, spoke against critics of the government reform program: ``They can inflict irreparable damage. We must put those hecklers in their places. They are guided only by their ambitions and not the interests of the people.'' But criticism has come not only from populists like Yeltsin, but from the mainstream press. A commentary written by economist Yegor Gaidar in Sunday's edition of the Communist Party daily, Pravda, said: ``with each passing day, it becomes clearer that to try to balance between the market and administrative measures is impossible, that traditional commands are not working, and that the center is losing control.'' He called for a swifter transition to a market economy. The government newspaper Izvestia ran a commentary, written by Eduard Gonzalez, calling for a nationwide referendum on the reform plan.

DOC.HEAD: Long-Shot Winds Fastest Indy 500 Ever
DOC.TEXT: Arie Luyendyk of the Netherlands won the fastest Indianapolis 500 ever Sunday, his first Indy-car victory on any track. Luyendyk, 36, who had never before even led a lap at Indy, passed former winner Bobby Rahal for the lead on lap 168 and pulled away, running laps at over 220 mph whenever he had a clear track. His average speed of 185.984 mph broke Rahal's record of 170.722 in 1986, and produced the fastest 500-mile Indy-car race ever, breaking the mark of 180.654 set by Danny Sullivan at Michigan in 1988. Luyendyk completed the 200 laps in just 2 hours, 41 minutes, 18.248 seconds. Defending champion Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil, who dominated the first half of the race, finished third, 41.7 seconds behind the winner, after being slowed by two blistered tires. Al Unser Jr. was fourth, followed by three-time winner Rick Mears and four-time winner A.J. Foyt. Luyendyk, the 1985 rookie of the year when he finished seventh for his only previous top 10 Indy finish, was second in a road race at Portland, Ore., in 1988 in his best previous Indy-car effort. ``I can't believe this is happening,'' he said in Victory Lane. ``The car was just working beautifully,'' said Luyendyk. ``With 35, 30 laps to go, I turned it up and there was just nobody who could keep up with us. For me it wasn't a very hard race at all. ``I said if I had to win my first race, I'd want it to be Indianapolis, but I'm going to have to let this one sink in.'' The winner is expected to earn a payoff of more than $1 million when the total purse, likely more than $6 million, is announced at the victory banquet Monday night. The race drew a crowd of more than 400,000. Sullivan, the 1985 winner, hit the wall on lap 20 between turns one and two after something broke in his rear suspension. He complained of dizziness and was taken to a hospital for examination, but was released before the end of the race.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Sentenced To Three Years For Desecrating Jewish Graves
DOC.TEXT: A court Sunday sentenced a messianic Jew to three years in prison after he confessed to desecrating more than 300 Jewish graves in hopes Arabs would be blamed. The spray-painting of the Jewish gravestones with anti-Israeli slogans received widespread publicity, coming just after the discovery of the desecration of a Jewish cemetery in Carpentras, France, on May 10. In the Carpentras incident, a recently buried body was dug up and impaled on the pole of an umbrella. It provoked outrage in France. The sentenced Israeli, 41-year-old David Goldner, said he regretted his action. He declared that at the time, he had hoped it would unite Jews against Arabs. Also charged in the incident in this coastal city was Gershon Tannenbaum, 32, who also confessed. His sentencing has been put off pending a psychiatric examination. Both men belong to a group that practices a mystical form of Judaism and hopes to hasten the arrival of the Messiah. Judge Amirav Rand of Haifa Magistrates Court imposed the maximum sentence and told Goldner if he had wanted to wake up the Israeli people to perceived dangers from Arabs, 30 graves would have been enough. Goldner refused to discuss his sentence when he left court, but told reporters: ``A war is expected soon, and the Prophet Elijah will come.'' According to the Scriptures, the prophet will signal the arrival of the Messiah. Goldner was to be transferred Monday from jail to a permanent prison facility.

DOC.HEAD: Florida And Central Part Of Nation Wet, Maybe Snow In California
DOC.TEXT: Rain spread over much of the central part of the nation Sunday, heavy rain drenched parts of parched Florida, and there was a threat of snow in the mountains of northern California. Near-continuous rain from a low-pressure area in the southeastern Gulf of Mexico mixed with remnants of this year's first tropical depression Sunday to drench much of southern Florida. The heaviest rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT was 2.88 inches at Miami; 2.14 inches at West Palm Beach, Fla.; and 2.09 inches at Columbus, Miss. Standing water on freeways contributed to accidents, police said. And rain delayed a regional college baseball tournament at the University of Miami in Coral Gables. At game time Sunday afternoon, groundskeepers were playing on a raft in the flooded outfield. At midday, showers and thunderstorms extended from central and southeastern Oklahoma to south-central through northwestern Kansas, northeastern Texas, western Arkansas, northeastern Louisiana, eastern Arkansas, southeastern Missouri, western Tennessee, Mississippi, northern Alabama, northern Georgia and western South Carolina. Wind gusted to 54 mph during thunderstorms in Chattanooga, Tenn. Showers were scattered over southwestern Wisconsin, southeastern Minnesota, northeastern Iowa, eastern and southwestern Nebraska and western North Dakota. In the East, scattered showers fell over northern and central New England. A cold storm system moved across the Pacific Coast and showers extended from the northern half of California to northwestern Nevada, western and central Oregon, and from south-central through western Washington. During the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT, 1.75 inches of rain fell at Crescent City, Calif., on the coast near the Oregon state line. Locally heavy rain was possible in the valleys and lower elevations of northern California and advisories for snow were posted into early Monday over higher elevations of the Mount Shasta-Siskiyou area and for the Sierra Nevada north of Yosemite National Park. Snow also was expected across higher elevations of northern and central Nevada. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 46 degrees at Tahoe Valley, Calif., to 99 at Sanderson, Texas. Sunday's low for the Lower 48 states was 28 degrees at West Yellowstone, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Homes Evacuated Around Area of Abandoned Chemical Plant
DOC.TEXT: Soil saturated with flammable and toxic chemicals caught fire around an abandoned chemical plant, prompting firefighters to evacuate residents of a sparsely populated desert area. No injuries were reported during the emergency that began Saturday night and ended early Sunday, said Kern County Fire Capt. Kenneth Frasca. Firefighters said the blaze started with a grass fire that swept toward the abandoned chemical plant, which contained barrels of cyanide, flammable chemicals, mercury and oxidizers. ``We didn't have the barrels on fire, but the chemicals in the dirt were burning, if you can picture that,'' said Frasca. He said there were several chemicals in the soil around the plant, which has been under a cleanup order by several agencies, including the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, for the past year. Frasca said the chemicals in the soil were the same as the materials stored in barrels, but mixed together from leaks and spills over the years. Authorities estimated that residents of about 75 to 100 scattered houses, mobile homes, apartments and a motel in the area 65 miles north of Los Angeles were evacuated. About 30 firefighters from the Kern County Fire Department were sent to the blaze, said dispatcher Denise Avalos. An engine company from nearby Edwards Air Force Base also was sent to help, Avalos said.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Calls Right-wing Party `Dangerous'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with de Klerk comment, ADDS ANC-army officers' accord. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk on Sunday launched a harsh attack on pro-apartheid whites, saying the country's leading right-wing movement had become ``irresponsible, undemocratic and dangerous.'' De Klerk's denunciation of the Conservative Party came after 50,000 right-wing whites rallied Saturday and vowed to resist de Klerk's plans to dismantle the nation's system of racial segregation. The rally in the capital of Pretoria was the largest pro-apartheid demonstration since de Klerk came to power in August and began a series of reforms. At the rally Saturday, the leader of the Conservatives, Andries Treurnicht, told his supporters that whites would fight moves to bring about a black government. ``The so-called New South Africa of forced integration, which the government is forcing on us, gives us no other choice but to defend our rights,'' Treurnicht said. De Klerk rejected that stance Sunday. ``The Conservative Party's threats of revolt and resistance are irresponsible, undemocratic and dangerous to our country,'' de Klerk was quoted as saying in Monday's editions of The Nationalist, the official publication of his ruling National Party. The comments, among the strongest he has leveled against the right wing to date, were made available on Sunday night. De Klerk said ``radicalism'' by the Conservatives could lead to ``broedertwis,'' or a fight between brothers. The Conservatives won 31 percent of the vote in white elections last year and are the official opposition in the dominant white chamber of Parliament. The party favors rigid apartheid and says blacks should have political rights only in tribal homelands. De Klerk has said he wants to end discrimination and negotiate a new constitution that will allow the 5 million whites to share power with the 28 million blacks. Nelson Mandela, leader of the African National Congress, the country's largest black opposition group, on Saturday accused de Klerk of not moving fast enough to end apartheid. Mandela, speaking at a rally near Pretoria, also said his organization felt de Klerk ``is not strong enough to end the violence going on.'' Mandela was referring to both black factional fighting in Natal province and the actions of the police, who have fired on black demonstrators several times in recent weeks, resulting in more than 20 deaths. Police said Sunday morning that nine blacks had been killed in the preceding 24 hours in a series of new faction fights in Natal. About 4,000 blacks have died in the region since 1986. In another development Sunday, African National Congress guerrilla commanders and veteran officers of the white-led South African army ended an unprecedented conference pledging to work for peace. In a joint statement released in the Zambian capital of Lusaka after five days of talks, the two sides declared there should be a ``mutually binding cessation of hostilities'' as soon as possible. The conference, convened to discuss the present and future role of the security forces, did not have the approval of South African Defense Minister Magnus Malan. But the 48 current and former military officers who attended said they would make recommendations privately to the government on their return home.

DOC.HEAD: Vonnegut: Skepticism More Valuable Than Cynicism
DOC.TEXT: Some icons of American history are not what they claim, author Kurt Vonnegut Jr. told University of Rhode Island graduates Sunday. Vonnegut told about 2,700 graduates that while Boston and Philadelphia both claim to be the ``birthplace of liberty,'' freedom was ``only conceived there, so Boston and Philadelphia were only motels of liberty.'' ``The gestation period of American liberty has taken 200 years or more,'' said Vonnegut, whose satiric novels take darkly humorous looks at the past, present and future. ``Don't be cynical about the American experiment because it has only now begun,'' said Vonnegut, author of ``Breakfast of Champions,'' ``Cat's Cradle,'' ``Slaughterhouse Five'' and 11 other novels. Vonnegut, whose new novel, ``Hocus Pocus, or What's the Hurry, Son,'' is due out in September, left the crowd with two ``highly personal opinions.'' ``One, the noblest of all professions are nursing and teaching ... and two, no matter where you are, even in the U.S. Army, there will be at least one saint. And it might even be you,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Source Denies Claim of Nuclear Test in Nevada
DOC.TEXT: A source close to the nation's weapons testing program on Sunday denied claims by anti-nuclear activists that the United States recently conducted a nuclear test. ``It would really be foolhardy to conduct a nuclear test this close to the Bush-Gorbachev summit,'' the source said of the upcoming meeting in Washington between the U.S. and Soviet leaders. The source, who spoke to the Associated Press on condition of anonymity, flatly denied that the United States conducted any recent test. Activists attending a worldwide gathering against nuclear testing reported that the United States detonated a nuclear weapon underground Friday at the Nevada Test Site, 65 miles northwest of Las Vegas. The comments came at a conference in Alma Ata, U.S.S.R., a city in the Soviet Union near the Russian nuclear test site of Semipalatinsk. Anti-nuclear activists from around the world, including the United States and Soviet Union, are attending the four-day conference. Dr. Bernard Lown, an organizer of the conference and president of International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, said he was ``ashamed and angered'' at the reports of a nuclear test in the United States. ``This makes no sense,'' Lown said. ``Why are we conducting nuclear tests just a few days before the summit?'' The American source agreed, and said it was a mystery as to where the anti-nuclear activists heard of a test. All U.S. and British tests are conducted at the Nevada site. Larger tests are announced in advance and smaller tests are revealed after the fact. In past years, some tests have not been announced for security reasons. It is believed in recent years that all tests have been announced, although the government continues to maintain an official policy that some tests may not be announced. The United States conducts about a dozen tests a year at the desert site.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Leaders Gather for Emergency Summit on Soviet Jewry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS two grafs for 4-5 bgng `The Arabs...' to UPDATE with Israeli reaction. Pickup pvs 6th graf `The Baghdad...' EDITS to TRIM
DOC.TEXT: Arab leaders who want to stop the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel gathered Sunday to forge a united front on the issue, but divisions and rivalries were at work even before the emergency summit began. The 21-member Arab league was also expected to criticize the United States for its support of Israel. In a move certain to draw anger at the Arab gathering, Israel said Sunday it expected the number of Soviet immigrants to increase to 20,000 per month this summer. About 40,000 Soviet Jews have arrived so far this year. The Arabs see the new wave of Jewish emigration, coupled with Israel's rejection of recent peace proposals, as a threat. They fear many Soviet Jews will settle in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, which the Palestinians proclaimed their homeland in 1988. Israeli officials deny there are plans to settle the Soviet Jews in the occupied areas and force out the Palestinian inhabitants. In Jerusalem, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's aide, Avi Pazner, quoted Shamir as saying he hoped the summit meeting will ``not pour fuel on to the fire, but to the contrary will also contribute to improving the atmosphere, maybe by agreeing to negotiations with Israel.'' Shamir has repeatedly called for Arab nations to enter into direct talks with Israel. The Baghdad summit will underscore old disputes that have blocked efforts to forge Arab unity. Syrian President Hafez Assad, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's arch-rival in the Arab world, refused to attend. So did four other heads of state, although some will send high-level officials in their place. Assad, miffed that the summit is being held in his rival's capital, rebuffed intensive Arab efforts _ including a last-minute effort by Libya's Moammar Gadhafi _ to persuade him to end his 11-year-old feud with Saddam in the interest of Arab unity. ``The summit will get under way with us unable to project even a semblance of unity,'' said an Arab diplomat from the Persian Gulf region, speaking on condition of anonymity. Fifteen presidents, kings and sheiks of the Arab world, which stretches from the Persian Gulf to the Atlantic, jetted into Baghdad airport Sunday to a red-carpet welcome from Saddam. Among them were King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, King Hussein of Jordan and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. Fahd's presence particularly was seen as a major boost for the summit. Amid tight security, the international airport was closed to regular traffic as the leaders arrived. Saddam greeted each as a military band played national anthems and the military fired 21-gun salutes. The rift between Syria and Iraq was not likely to be a key issue at the summit. But one of the main differences will be between those who favor getting tough with the United States, Israel's main backer, and those who seek a more moderate line. Iraq and the Palestine Liberation Organization, which is an Arab League member, want to take a tough line. The moderates are led by Egypt and oil-rich Saudi Arabia. A 16-page memorandum from Washington, delivered to Arab foreign ministers who met in Baghdad last week to pave the way for the summit, touched off an uproar by urging the Arabs to avoid rhetoric, focus on direct Arab-Israeli negotiations and avoid outright denunications of Soviet Jewish emigration. The memorandum also accused Iraq, which boasts it has developed binary chemical weapons and long-range missiles capable of hitting Israeli cities, of violating international conventions banning use of chemical and biological weapons. Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz angrily dismissed the American document as ``inaccurate and insensitive.'' PLO leader Yasser Arafat, an ally of Saddam, called last month for the summit to discuss ways to blunt Soviet Jewish emigration to Israel and revive the stalled peace process. The summit follows a new wave of violence in the Israeli-occupied territories touched off by the May 20 slaying of seven unarmed Palestinian laborers near Tel Aviv by a former Israeli soldier. Israeli authorities said the gunman was deranged. Saddam and the PLO insisted the summit convene ahead of the May 31 meeting between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, with the apparent intention of focussing the superpowers' attention on their problems. Lebanese President Elias Hrawi has said that, like Assad, he will not attend the summit. Two-thirds of his war-ravaged country is under Syrian military control. Conference sources said President Chadli Bendjedid of Algeria will not attend in sympathy with Syria, and King Hassan of Morocco also will not participate; conference sources said he hates flying. But those leaders will send high-level delegations. Sultan Qaboos of Oman also announced that he will send an envoy to represent him.

DOC.HEAD: Teams Fight Over Rules and History, But St. Ubaldo Always Wins
DOC.TEXT: The only thing certain about the annual Memorial Day weekend Race of the Saints is that the 800-pound statue of St. Ubaldo crosses the finish line first. Beyond that, there are debates about the rules, about which team really is the fastest and about why St. Ubaldo is celebrated every May. ``Symbolically, whenever we have the race, it's always 'Baldo first,'' said Ron Tomko of the Society of St. Anthony. This northeastern Pennsylvania town of 5,000 people was settled by natives of Gubbio, Italy, which claims Ubaldo as its patron saint. In most years since 1911, teams from the societies of Saints George and Anthony challenged members of St. Ubaldo to a Race of the Saints, with each team carrying an 800-pound statue of their saint atop a platform through the 1{-mile course. To honor him, St. Ubaldo always goes first and the rules make it easy for him to stay out front: each team starts 63 feet apart and there is no passing. The truth, according to Tomko, is that St. Anthony would be the best in an un-rigged race, but across town, another group claims superiority. ``St. George has always had the strongest team in the race, at least for the last 10 years,'' said Mario Mariani, a captain of the St. George's team. ``If you watch the race, you'll see the distance St. Anthony is behind.'' The only team not claiming to be the fastest during Saturday's race was St. Ubaldo's, which was shorthanded and had to stray from the rules and borrow men from the other teams to help carry its statue. The race is similar to one held the last 799 years in Gubbio on May 15, the eve of the real St. Ubaldo's Day, with teams carrying 1,200-pound statues over a longer, steeper course. The feast is celebrated in Jessup every Memorial Day weekend, ending at the Jessup Memorial Stadium. In an added twist, each team dismantles its platform and races its statue up a hillside. In this second race, it's anybody's ball game, not just Ubaldo's. St. Anthony's won the second race Saturday. There are several theories on why St. Ubaldo is honored. Most say Ubaldo rescued Gubbio by negotiating with a barbarian who was ravaging the Italian countryside or that Ubaldo was a philanthropist who spread his wealth among townspeople while accepting a life of poverty for himself.

DOC.HEAD: Residue from Illegally Dumped Chemicals May Have Caused Ship Explosion
DOC.TEXT: The captain and two crew members of a Panamanian ship which exploded in the Houston Ship Channel may have caused the blast by illegally dumping hazardous chemicals, federal authorities said. The fire started May 11 while the 375-foot chemical tanker Seta was moored for repairs at Newpark Shipyard. The 25 crewmen aboard when the Seta exploded jumped into the ship channel. Federal authorities think residue from chemicals illegally dumped into the ship channel may have been ignited by a spark from a welding torch on an adjacent vessel in dry dock, and the fire spread to the tanker, said Coast Guard Lt. Mary Landry. Cargo tanks had residue from recent hazardous cargoes of acetone, toluene, caustic soda, mineral spirits, xylene, hexane and kerosene. The captain and two crew members were arrested Friday. Goran Bacic, the ship's captain, and Klause Eheler, the port captain, were charged with felony violation of the Clean Water Act, which carries up to a $50,000 fine and three years in prison, officials said. Doran Prpic, the second-ranking officer, was charged with a misdemeanor violation of the Clean Water Act. Bacic and Prpic are Yugoslavian, and Eheler is German, officials said. They were released on bond, which was set at $100,000 on the felony charges and $25,000 on the misdemeanor charge, officials said. The ship channel was closed to regular traffic while firefighters battled the blaze for 12 hours. Three crew members were burned and several firefighters suffered heat stroke. The Coast Guard, FBI and federal Environmental Protection Agency are conducting a joint investigation, FBI spokesman Charles B. Kearney said. The fire caused an estimated $2 million in damage, but Ms. Landry said there was little environmental harm.

DOC.HEAD: Death Row Inmate Suing to Worship Satan
DOC.TEXT: A man scheduled to be the first Arkansas death row inmate executed in more than a quarter century is suing the state over his right to worship the devil. But officials see the suit as just another ploy by John Edward Swindler to stay alive. Swindler is to be put to death June 18 for the 1976 shooting death of a Fort Smith police officer. Because he was sentenced before the state switched its method of executions, Swindler has the choice of dying in the electric chair or by lethal injection, the state standard. No Arkansas prisoner has been put to death since 1964. Earlier this month, the U.S. Supreme Court refused to consider Swindler's appeal. A district court judge then granted the state's motion to withdraw a 9-year-old stay of execution in the case. Swindler, who has sued the prison system numerous times over alleged mistreatment on death row, has joined another inmate's lawsuit against prison officials for being prohibited from reading the satanic bible. Prison officials contend Swindler is trying use the lawsuit as another roadblock to his execution. ``He'll attack the system in any way he can,'' prison spokesman David White said recently. ``I don't think he shows any strong religious inclinations.'' But Swindler, who is at the state's maximum-security unit in Tucker in southeastern Arkansas, adamantly lays claims to his religious roots. ``I am a Satanist,'' he wrote in a letter to a reporter last summer. He said he and fellow inmate John E. Campbell ``will let the prison administrators know we are true Satanists and want the right to practice my faith and worship my lord Lucifer.'' ``To me it shows their lack of their faith in their God of Christianity when they refuse my religion,'' Swindler wrote. Court records show that in his last hearing in federal court, Swindler told jurors he was a Quaker. Campbell, who is serving a life sentence at the maximum-security unit for aggravated robbery and attempted murder, filed the original lawsuit in December 1988, and Swindler intervened later. Named as defendants are Prison Director A.L. ``Art'' Lockhart, warden Larry Norris and prison chaplain Dennis Pigman. Campbell is seeking permission to read the satanic bible and to wear a mail-order medallion, in addition to $330,000 in damages. Swindler also wants to read the satanic bible and asks that the prison create satanic religious services. Federal law authorizes prison wardens to censor prisoners' reading materials if the materials are deemed disruptive. White said he could not comment on pending litigation, but acknowledged that the warden had prohibited the prisoners from reading the satanic bible. Swindler is on death row for the murder of Fort Smith police officer Randy Basnett. He also was convicted of murdering two South Carolina teen-agers and is suspected in the death of a young hitchhiker in Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Six Killed in Shootout at Yerevan Train Station
With AM-Soviet-Reforms, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Armenian reax, reported death toll up to 15. Pickup 9th graf pvs `Armenia has...'
