DOC.TEXT: Soviet soldiers killed at least six people in a clash Sunday at a train station in Yerevan, the capital of the restive republic of Armenia. Ten government troopers and two other people were reported wounded. The official Tass news agency said the violence broke out when militants opened fire on a group of soldiers returning from a patrol. However, a spokesman for an Armenian group said the soldiers had started the clash by opening fire. He said 15 people were killed. The attack was the latest violence in the tense Caucasus republic, but the first time the clashes spread to a public place in Yerevan. Ten Interior Ministry soldiers were wounded in the shooting, three critically, and one civilian bystander was hospitalized with bullet wounds, Tass said. The soldiers were attacked by about 15 armed men when they returned from escorting a passenger train to Kafan, 120 miles southeast of Yerevan, Tass said. The southeastern corner of Armenia near Kafan has become one of the tensest areas in the dispute between Armenians and Azerbaijanis over control of the Nagorno-Karabakh region. ``The personnel, exercising their right to repulse an attack, returned fire,'' Tass said. ``Five militants were killed and two were injured in the shootout. One of the injured soon died.'' Tass provided no other details. Officials of the Interior Ministry in Yerevan said they were not authorized to release information. Unrest continued throughout the day in Yerevan, as crowds of up to 50,000 people roamed the streets after the shooting incident, according to a duty officer at the Armenian National Movement in Yerevan who was contacted by telephone. The spokesman, who declined to give his name, blamed soldiers for starting the incident by firing on a group of Armenians. The Armenian spokesman put the death toll at 15, including one young woman. It was impossible to determine which version of events was correct. Armenia has been locked in a bitter dispute for more than two years with Azerbaijan over control of Nagorno-Karabakh. That region is predominantly ethnic Armenian, but legally belongs to Azerbaijan. Several hundred people have been killed and hundreds of thousands have been forced to flee their homes in more than two years of ethnic attacks and clashes between civilians and soldiers. Soviet soldiers are stationed in both republics to quell violence, but militants on both sides see the troops as an occupying force. The shootout came three days after militants fired on soldiers at military checkpoints and on a patrol in Nagorno-Karabakh, killing one serviceman and wounding four. Tass said soldiers killed one attacker and wounded six.

DOC.HEAD: Poles Vote For Local Council Members
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9 grafs for grafs 11-18 bgng ```This vote...' to UPDATE with voter turnout, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WAR1
DOC.TEXT: Poles voted Sunday for community councils nationwide and were expected to push forward the country's democratic revolution by ousting Communists from their last bastions of power. The vote was the first fully free ballot since World War II and aims to reinstitute local governments that are entirely autonomous of Warsaw. That system was not allowed under four decades of Communist Party rule. Unofficial results of the 52,000 individual races were expected on Monday, but official results were not expected until Wednesday. Solidarity Citizens Committees are expected to dominate local governments, but the vote will be a test of the country's budding independent political parties. ``The vast majority of society _ although angry at the bad (economic) situation _ understands that we must stick together because there is no other choice,'' Solidarity Chairman Lech Walesa said after voting near Gdansk. ``We must take over power from the bottom and build the foundations of democracy.'' Voting in Warsaw, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki said the balloting was fundamental: ``Local government elections will not change the economic situation. But we can say they are changing the system.'' Senate Speaker Andrzej Stelmachowski said the vote ``finally will anchor democracy to the very bottom, to the grassroots. ... After this, our changes will be truly irreversible.'' In previous local elections held under the Communists, only those candidates approved by party-dominated nominating boards were allowed to run. The local councils, considered the agents of the central government, depended on Warsaw for money and their decisions could be overturned. The election of local officials answerable to residents and not to Warsaw should make administration of towns and villages more efficient, Mazowiecki said. More than 146,000 candidates from about 80 parties were vying nationwide. Official posters outside polling places listed the names of district candidates and the parties they represented. ``Finally we have real elections, and I went to all those elections before, so I know the difference,'' said Jozef Szewicz, a doctor leaving a polling station with his wife. ``Thank God that I lived to see this,'' said Janina Krakowska, who worked on a farm in the town of Wiskitki until she retired. There was little of the enthusiasm displayed during last June's partly free parliamentary elections, when Solidarity plastered towns with posters and manned stands outside polling places. Politicking was illegal Sunday. The final turnout was 42 percent nationwide, according to the General Election Commission. In June's parliamentary elections, the turnout was 62 percent. ``There were fewer preparations, fewer posters because we didn't want people to say we were wasting money,'' said Maria Simiatowska of the Solidarity Citizens Committee in Skierniewice, a provincial capital 30 miles southwest of Warsaw. The June parliamentary vote was governed by an agreement between Solidarity and the former Communist government. The accord reserved 65 percent of the seats in the lower house of parliament, the Sejm, for the Communists and their allies, and 35 percent for non-party independents. In that vote, Solidarity candidates won all non-party seats by wide margins. In August Solidarity took over a coalition government, the first non-Communist leadership in the East bloc. Since then, an entirely new system of local government has been drafted and approved by parliament. Local governments will be given one-fifth of the central government's vast property and will be empowered to raise and spend revenues independently of Warsaw. Mazowiecki and Walesa have both called for parliamentary elections next spring in which no seats would be set aside for any political party.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Lithuanian, German Issues Could Hurt Talks With Gorbachev
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts 8th graf, ``Gorbachev went xxx to update with Soviet leader's TV appeal and Bush response
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, in an interview broadcast Sunday in the Soviet Union, said ``we've got big differences'' with Mikhail S. Gorbachev over German unity and Lithuania that could impede this week's superpower summit. While hailing Gorbachev as a statesman, Bush said, ``He may be mad with me over some things because we do have some differences.'' Bush said he would not try to exploit any weakness suffered by Gorbachev because of economic problems and ethnic unrest in the Soviet Union. ``I think that when you sit down with a respected world leader, it's not a question of who is stronger, who is weaker, who has got bigger problems, who has got less problems,'' the president said. He promised to treat the Soviet people and their leader ``with the respect that they deserve.'' Bush said that ``If we argue, we'll do that pleasantly. He's a tough guy. Listen, I've been around him enough to know that he drives his point home. ``Well, I can do the same thing,'' Bush said. ``And I think it's important that I level with him _ here's what's in my heart, here's our policy.'' Gorbachev went on television Sunday night to appeal for calm amid panic in the Soviet Union over imminent food price hikes. Bush, as he finished a round of golf Sunday, was asked about Gorbachev's appeal. ``It's a big problem,'' said Bush. Bush and Gorbachev will meet at the White House beginning Thursday. On Friday, they are to sign an agreement to destroy chemical weapons and outline limits on cruise missiles, which have been an obstacle to agreement on a strategic nuclear weapons pact. The two leaders will go to the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., on Saturday for more talks and then conduct a wrapup news conference Sunday at the White House. In a round of pre-summit jockeying, Bush administration leaders and a Soviet official made appearances Sunday on television talk shows. Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said it would be impossible for the superpowers to sign an agreement banning long-range missiles although the two sides are making progress on negotiations. But Scowcroft said arms control will not be the focus of the summit. ``The fundamental issues are talking about remaking the political map of Europe and also, secondarily, what is going on it the Soviet Union,'' Scowcroft said on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley.'' Scowcroft was also adamant that the United States would not grant trade benefits, known as most favored nation status, to the Soviet Union until the Moscow passes immigration laws that allow citizens to leave the country freely. Bush, who arrived here Friday for a four-day, pre-summit vacation, was interviewed Thursday at the White House by Soviet TV correspondent Valentin Zorin for a Sunday night broadcast in the Soviet Union. A text of Bush's remarks was released here. Bush spoke repeatedly of obstacles in U.S.-Soviet relations, particularly coercion of Lithuania and German unity. ``And so we've got big differences on some of these questions. ... ``We've got some problems in the Baltic states that inhibit total openness here,'' the president said. ``We've got some problems in what we think _ reforms need to be taking place before we can have the full exchange of economic interests there.'' Gorbachev, in an interview published in this week's issue of Time magazine, said the German unity question was certain to produce a major disagreement with Bush. But, Gorbachev said, ``I do expect the differences to be narrowed.'' Bush said he would try to convince Gorbachev there would be no threat to the Soviet Union from having a united Germany in the U.S.-led NATO alliance. However, Soviet and American officials held out little hope that Gorbachev could be persuaded. ``I didn't say we could,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III said on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation'' program. ``I said we will have to try because the position we have is very firmly held and we're not going to come off of that position.'' Soviet Politburo member Aleksandr Yakovlev, reflecting Moscow's fears of a militarily strong Germany, said, ``We shall do everything in our power to guarantee to the Soviet Union, to the Soviet people, that no war will ever start from the German soil, that there will be no threat to our people. ``That is our principal concern and we turn to the West, we appeal to the West, to take this point of view of the Soviet Union into account,'' said Yakovlev, an adviser to Gorbachev. He was interviewed on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press.'' Bush said ``I want to convince Mr. Gorbachev _ with whom I can talk freely, he's the kind of man you can very frankly with _ that a U.S. presence in Europe, a unified Germany, a Germany in NATO not only is no threat to the Soviet Union, but preserves the kind of stable Europe that the Soviets should welcome.'' He called Soviet pressure against the breakaway republic of Lithuania an issue that is ``troubling that I don't want to sweep under this rug. ... ``And I have to have him understand the constraints on any U.S. president until self-determination is visible and forthcoming there.''

DOC.HEAD: Autopsy Set for Body that Medium Failed to Revive
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Chhim is correct.
DOC.TEXT: A man apparently died while visiting a spiritual medium, who then spent a week trying to revive him, authorities said. Horn Kim Chhim, 50, suffered from a stomach ailment but did not believe in doctors, authorities said Saturday. His body was to undergo an autopsy Monday or Tuesday. Authorities said it was unlikely the medium would be charged with any crime. ``There was strange activity, but nothing criminal,'' said Los Angeles County Sheriff's Sgt. Scott Coleman. The medium was not identified and his beliefs and practices were not described. He said relatives told sheriff's investigators that Chhim was suffering from a stomach ailment when he was taken to the medium's home on May 18 ``for religious reasons.'' Although authorities were uncertain of the date of Chhim's death, it appeared that he was with the medium when he died, officials said. The medium then asked the family to allow him to keep the corpse in an attempt to restore the dead man's spirit. ``Apparently the medium told the family he could bring the body back to life, and after they gave it to him for a week and the body didn't come back to life, he gave it back,'' Coleman said. On Friday, family members called paramedics to the dead man's home in this city just east of Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Niagara Falls Jet Boat Capsizes, Throwing Seven Into Water
DOC.TEXT: A controversial tour boat capsized Sunday in rapids a few hundred yards below Niagara Falls, throwing seven people into the cold waters of the Niagara River. No one aboard the 23-foot jet boat was seriously hurt, according to Niagara Parks Police Constable Steve Kelly. Two people, including a Yugoslavian tourist, were treated at Greater Niagara General Hospital for hypothermia and released, a nursing supervisor said. Three passengers on the Jet Boat International tour swam to safety on the U.S. side of the river below the bridge connecting Queenston and Lewiston, N.Y. ``We hit the (rapids) and we then came back again to have another go at it and that's when we went over,'' passenger John Swan said. The company started its Niagara River tours two weeks ago despite warnings from U.S. and Canadian authorities it would not be safe. Swan, president of a winery in nearby Niagara-on-the-Lake, said he didn't know what caused the accident. ``All of a sudden I was under the boat,'' he said. ``I gradually made my way to the shore ...'' Canadian and U.S. rescue teams and a tourist helicopter company helped rescue the seven people. Jet Boat International owner Jim McLean declined to comment on the accident. When Jet Boat International started its excursions for ``thrill-seekers,'' a senior marine surveyor for the Canadian Coast Guard said he was skeptical about whether the waters were safe enough to navigate. Canadian and American law prohibit anyone from launching boats into the Niagara River from public lands, but the company got around the regulation by launching its craft from a private yacht club. The company is the first to operate tours on the river since three people were killed in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Former Hostage Reed Comes Home to Massachusetts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT that Reed and mother did not meet behind closed doors.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: Freed hostage Frank Reed's joyous reunion Sunday with his 91-year-old mother was tempered with an urgent plea for the speedy release of the six Americans still held captive. ``They aren't well,'' he implored after arriving at Boston's Logan International Airport. ``They are sick. I promise you they are sick. Let us not forget them.'' Reed, who has been undergoing medical tests at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland, saw his mother for the first time in eight years in a tearful airport reunion before meeting reporters. ``He said to me, `You're a great mother.' We shed tears of joy,'' said Leota Sprague, who was too weak to join her son earlier. ``I say rejoice, give thanks.'' ``She looks lovely,'' said Reed with his mother at his side. She was in a wheelchair. The Reed family, including his wife, Fahima, and 9-year-old son, Tarek, traveled by motorcade to his daughter's house in this suburb just north of Boston, where cheering neighbors and 100 yellow ribbons awaited the hometown celebrity. The suburb of 56,000 planned a parade for Reed on Tuesday. Reed, 57, was released April 30 after 44 months in captivity in Lebanon. He was home for a brief Memorial Day break but was scheduled to return Wednesday to the Malcolm Grow Medical Center at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland. Reed said doctors were trying to do some ``medical sleuthing'' to find out why he is so anemic. ``We're trying to do some things to verify the contusions and results of the beatings I had for trying to escape twice, not really being left alone until a few months ago,'' Reed said. ``Despite it all, they say my heart's fine, my lungs are fine, my liver's fine.'' Reed also spoke out on behalf of the other hostages he said were in ill health. His comments contradicted those he made at a Washington news conference May 6, when he told reporters the American hostages ``look physically wonderful.'' ``Terry Anderson is not well,'' he said of the longest held of the hostages. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is in his sixth year of captivity. ``Thomas Sutherland is not well,'' added Reed, who last saw the hostages more than a year ago. ``And I told the people in Washington that they are not well. We must do something. We must get the other hostages free somehow.'' Reed's spokesman and attorney, Bob Woolf, deflected further questions about the hostages' conditions and the U.S. government's attempts to secure their freedom. ``This weekend we are memorializing the dead that fought for our country,'' said Reed, who was flanked by family members at the airport news conference. ``Let us hope that one day we don't have to have a day to memorialize the hostages that are dead or will die.'' The other Americans still held hostage are Joseph James Cicippio, 59, who was acting comptroller at the American University in Beirut; Edward Austin Tracy, 59, a west Beirut resident; Alann Steen, 51, a communications instructor at Beirut University College, and Jesse Jonathan Turner, 42, a professor of mathematics and computer science at Beirut University College. A banner hanging in front of the home of Reed's daughter, Marilyn Langston, read, ``Free at Last _ Frank Reed, April 30, 1990.'' Reed has two grown daughters from a previous marriage. Langston said her father had not been in Malden, where he grew up, since he made a week-long visit in March 1982. She said the visit would mark the first time her father had ever seen his granddaughter _ her 6-year-old daughter, Stacy _ and only the second time he had seen her 8-year-old son, Nathan. Reed, who has gained 18 pounds since returning to the United States, has been playing golf and dreaming of the lobster dinner he was planning to enjoy Sunday night with family members in Malden. Reed was head of the private Lebanese International School when he was snatched from his car by gunmen near the Beirut Airport in 1986. He was freed eight days after another American hostage, Robert Polhill, was released. Polhill remains hospitalized, undergoing treatment for cancer. They were the first Americans to be freed in 3{ years. After his release, Reed told reporters his Moslem kidnappers double-chained him to a wall or radiator, broke his nose, jaw and ribs, slightly fractured his feet with iron rods and bloodied his kidneys for twice trying to escape. Some military and administration officials have said there may be discrepancies in Reed's accounts of his captivity, and relatives said he was having problems with his short-term memory. Woolf, an attorney to celebrities and sports stars who said he had been asked to act as Reed's spokesman, said the freed hostage would likely remain hospitalized ``at least two more weeks'' after returning to the medical center. Woolf said Reed wanted to complete the doctoral work he had started at Boston College and continue his career as an educator. Reed has been ``deluged'' with movie and book offers and is very interested in writing about his experiences, Woolf said. ``Just listening to his experiences, I can see there's a great book in this,'' Woolf said.

DOC.HEAD: Family Plans For Possible Visit By Raisa Gorbachev
With AM-Summit-Memorial Day
DOC.TEXT: A family of six is trying hard to regard a possible social call from Raisa Gorbachev as something like a visit from a ``dear aunt.'' But the Watsons acknowledge they're thinking a lot about what they'll wear, whether they'll offer Mrs. Gorbachev something to eat and what they'll chat about with reporters and security officials nearby. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife said they would like to visit a home during their six-hour stay in the Twin Cities area next Sunday. The home of Steve and Karen Watson and their four children was recommended partly because their 13-year-old daughter, Lisa, performed in Moscow last year in an exchange between the Children's Theater Co. of Minneapolis and a Moscow children's theater. The Gorbachevs' itinerary has not been released, but the Watsons must prepare as if they were certain they'll be entertaining one or both. Karen Watson, 38, said a public relations expert gave them some advice. ``She told us to view it as a dear aunt coming to visit and keep it simple,'' Mrs. Watson said. Still, the Watsons can't shake the surreal quality of it all. ``It feels very strange that we should be given some of their time,'' Mrs. Watson said. ``We feel very honored and very lucky.'' Jon Cranney, artistic director of the Children's Theater Co., recommended the Watsons to members of Gov. Rudy Perpich's staff, who were looking for a typical middle-class home Gorbachev could visit. Steve Watson, 39, teaches art at Forest Hills Elementary School in Eden Prairie. Lisa also appeared in ABC-TV's miniseries filmed in the Twin Cities, ``The Voices Within: The Lives of Truddi Chase,'' which aired May 20-21. She portrayed a daughter of the title character played by Shelley Long. Lisa's 11-year-old sister, Stephanie, appeared in a 1987 production at Minneapolis' famed Guthrie Theater. The family also includes Tom, 7; Will, 6; and their dog, Bonnie, who is part golden retriever and part Irish setter. On Wednesday a Soviet advance team briefly visited the family's home on its tour of possible stops. Secret Service agents surveyed the white stucco home with green awnings for security purposes. Besides worrying about what to talk about, Mrs. Watson has another priority. ``I would like my house to be very, very clean,'' she said. ``If my house was very, very clean, I would be totally happy.''

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Candidates for Governor Return to Traditional Campaigns
DOC.TEXT: Two Democratic candidates for governor took to the pulpit in black churches at opposite ends of California on Sunday as each battled for grassroots support. State Attorney General John Van de Kamp unveiled a $7 billion-plus plan in Sacramento to build a ``world class'' passenger rail system in California by the end of the decade. In Los Angeles, former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein stuck to general themes in get-out-the-vote speeches. Van de Kamp's rail plan calls for passage of both Propositions 108 and 116, bond issues on the June 5 ballot that would raise $2.99 billion. That's enough, Van de Kamp says, to begin a project to link California's major cities with faster, more convenient passenger trains. ``It is time for this state to catch up to the rest of the world in rapid transit,'' Van de Kamp said. Van de Kamp, who took his campaign entourage on a 3{-hour train trip from Sacramento to Fresno, said the same distance could be covered by one of France's high-speed trains in about 80 minutes. Ms. Feinstein challenged herself and other politicians to be like black South African leader Nelson Mandela who, newly released from prison, must ``chart a course for the future, a course that says ... you can't deny equal opportunity, a course that says there has to be a level playing field if people are going to succeed in this world.'' She refused to elaborate on her pledge Saturday to make half the appointments in her administration women and to hire minorities by a quota system in proportion to their population. California is projected to be mostly nonwhite in 10 years. ``I see bringing people of color into a position of power in government,'' was all she would tell reporters Sunday. As the campaign for the Democratic nomination in the June 5 primary entered its final 10 days, Van de Kamp and Ms. Feinstein are returning to traditional campaigning with visits to churches. The two had concentrated earlier on raising funds for television advertisements. Van de Kamp delivered brief campaign speeches to two black Baptist congregations in Sacramento and a third in nearby North Highlands, stressing a message of politics as public service. ``I'm running because I think it's time we start to love one another again. I'm running to serve others,'' he told the congregation at the Antioch Baptist Church. ``I'd like it to be said of me someday, that I tried to feed the hungry _ not only tried but succeeded,'' he continued before the congregation of St. Paul's Baptist Church. Relaxed and gaining confidence at every stop, Ms. Feinstein told four congregations in the largely poor Watts and south-central sections of Los Angeles that her administration would bring better education and more opportunity for their children. She warmed to the rousing music and singing at the First African Methodist Episcopal Church near downtown that featured a choir of children and teen-age gospel singers. ``As we were sitting here getting a little soul, I was looking into a number of faces and wondering if in 10 years from today will we have a better state, will we have a safer community,'' she said. ``Will these young people, eyes bright, standing tall ... really be able to take their full place in a society that promises the American Dream?'' The Democratic contest has been marked by sharp shifts in public opinion. Feinstein was well ahead of Van de Kamp in early polls, but the next round of surveys showed her lagging behind in a double-digit deficit. Next, after she launched a media blitz, another poll moved her from 18 percentage points behind Van de Kamp to 19 points ahead. That lead soon evaporated, however, and a Los Angeles Times poll released earlier this month had her with a 13-point lead, 37 percent to 24 percent over Van de Kamp. The undecided vote was even higher, at 38 percent. On the Republican side, low-profile candidate Pete Wilson has no major opposition and is steadily raising money for the November general election.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Supreme Court Upholds Conviction of Nuclear Spy
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Sunday rejected an appeal by former nuclear technician Mordechai Vanunu, who was convicted of treason and spying for leaking details of Israel's nuclear weapons program to a British newspaper. The announcement by the three-judge panel was read behind closed doors, in keeping with the secrecy surrounding the case since Vanunu was arrested in 1986 after disappearing in London. The judges did not make public their reasons for rejecting the appeal and banned publication of their 89-page verdict. They gave Vanunu's attorney, Avigdor Feldman, 30 days to appeal the decision. Feldman told reporters he plans to ask for a larger panel of justices to rule on whether ``a man can be accused of treason for ties with a newspaper.'' Vanunu captured wideworld attention when The Sunday Times of London on Oct. 5, 1986, printed information and photographs he provided. The information detailed operations of an Israeli nuclear reactor near the town of Dimona in the Negev Desert and suggested that Israel had stockpiled at least 100 nuclear weapons and had the capability to produce neutron and hydrogen bombs. Israel has never responded directly to those allegations, and officials would only say that Israel will not be the first to introduce atomic weapons into the Middle East. Vanunu was convicted of treason and espionage in December 1988 and sentenced to 18 years in prison. During his trial, Vanunu testified he made his revelations to the newspaper to alert the world to the dangers of nuclear weapons _ not for personal gain or out of a desire to harm his country. Vanunu is being held in solitary confinement.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Thousands of Kids Work in New York Sweatshops
DOC.TEXT: Labor experts estimate that 5,000 to 10,000 children, many of them working grueling hours in hazardous conditions, are illegally employed in the city's garment industry every day, the Daily News reported Sunday. The trend has reached a level not seen since the turn of the century, when there were no child labor laws, the News said. It comes as apparel manufacturers struggle to compete with their rivals in Asia, where labor costs are lower. Ninety-nine percent of the minors are documented or undocumented aliens from Mexico, Latin America and Asia. They often are paid off the books, well below the minimum wage of $3.80 an hour. ``The situation is out of control and beyond the reach of regulation,'' said Stanley Aronowitz, a labor expert at City University. In the first three months of this year, the state Labor Department's Apparel Industry Task Force found 90 Garment District factories illegally employing 128 minors. It was the largest number of violators nabbed in any three-month period by the task force, which was created in 1987. The number of children documented as illegally employed in the city soared more than 900 percent, from 90 to 819, between 1983 and 1989, according to the state Labor Department. But task force officials said tracking down violators is an arduous, often frustrating job. There are 3,500 registered garment manufacturers in the city and an equal number that are unregistered and illegal. The task force has 24 investigators. The newspaper described how three children, illegal aliens from Mexico, worked 11 hours in a room filled with electrical hazards, solvent fumes, poor ventilation and fire hazards. The News said some teen-age alien workers seen during a task force sweep of eight garment operations last week appeared strained by the monotonous work and dilapidated surroundings. But others appeared content and conscientious. For them, even those conditions were better than no work. There also are widespread child labor law violations at restaurants, supermarkets and laundries, said Richard Polsinello, director of labor standards for the state Labor Department.

DOC.HEAD: Solar-Powered Commuter Car Wins Race
DOC.TEXT: A solar-powered commuter car Sunday won a 234-mile race against other sun-fueled vehicles and a free ride to an international competition in Switzerland, organizers said. The Solectria Lightspeed produced by Solectria Corp. of Arlington took first place in the commuter category with a time of 8.2 hours, crossing the finish line behind the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University in this Boston suburb. Fifteen solar-powered cars began the second annual race in Fairlee, Vt., on Wednesday. The commuter category consisted of useable two- and four-seaters, said race co-director Nancy Hazard. ``What we are really trying to promote is the development and use of commuter cars,'' Hazard said. The Solectria Lightspeed, driver Anita Rajan, and its crew will be flown to the Tour de Sol in June by Lufthansa German Airlines, said Rosemarie Van Camp, a Tufts official. Solectria Corp. also finished second in the commuter category with its Selectria Sunrise, at 8.23 hours. In the racing category, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's MIT Solectria 5 finished first at 6.2 hours. The Dartmouth Sunvox II came in second for solar racers at 7.9 hours. The University of California at Irvine's Solaris was the only entry in the cross-continental category. The car completed the race. The race was sponsored by the Northeast Solar Energy Association and private corporations, Hazard said.

DOC.HEAD: Korean Police Fire Tear Gas at Protesting Teachers
DOC.TEXT: Police fired tear gas Sunday and stormed a university to break up an anti-government rally by more than 4,000 teachers, students and dissidents. About a dozen protesters and police were injured in the clashes that lasted about 30 minutes. More than 20 protesters were detained. Authorities shot the tear gas from black armored vans, and about 800 riot police staged two raids on Kyunghee University. About 3,000 primary, middle and high school teachers were holding a rally there to protest the dismissals last year of about 5,000 teachers for involvement in an outlawed union. When police moved in firing tear gas Sunday, most of the teachers fled, but hundreds of students fought back with stones and firebombs. The rally marked the first anniversary of the founding of the outlawed National Teachers' Union. Protesters said teachers need an independent union to guard schools from government influence. They claimed Korea's past dictatorial governments used the educational system to justify its policies. In downtown Seoul, meanwhile, about 1,000 students mounted scattered anti-government street demonstrations. Police fired tear gas to break up the protests, and students hurled firebombs at the police. There were no reports of arrests.

DOC.HEAD: Mohawks Stage Peaceful Protest Over Police Presence on Reservation
DOC.TEXT: About 250 Mohawks staged a peaceful protest Sunday against the continued presence of police on this reservation. ``Basically, you still have martial law, even though they are allowing outside traffic to go through,'' said Harold Oakes, a spokesman for the protesters. The demonstration took place on the U.S. side of the 28,000-acre reservation, which covers parts of New York and the Canadian provinces of Ontario and Quebec. U.S. and Canadian police moved onto the reservation May 1 after two Mohawk men were shot dead in a feud between pro- and anti-gambling factions. New York state troopers allowed outside traffic onto the reserve late last week for the first time since March. However, they continue to stop and search vehicles within the reserve, and Ontario and Quebec provincial police continue to patrol Canadian sections of the reservation. Oakes said the situation is bad for businesses along Route 37, the reservation's main thoroughfare. The route, which bisects Indian land, is dotted with gas stations and restaurants, as well as the controversial casinos, which remain closed. ``We're still not sure whether the presence of armed police is going to have a negative effect on traffic through here,'' Oakes said. ``They might not stop here.'' The demonstrators also were protesting the release Wednesday of Doug George on $15,000 bail. George, the anti-gambling editor of the reservation's two newspapers, has been charged with second-degree murder in the May 1 shooting near Snye, Quebec, of Harold Edwards, 33, who was neutral in the gambling dispute. Quebec police are still investigating the May 1 shooting death of 22-year-old Matthew Pyke, who opposed gambling. Following Sunday's protest, the crowd gathered at a bingo hall for what turned out to be a rally for Norman Tarbell, who is running against Harold Tarbell in the June 2 election for the head chief of the Tribal Council that governs the U.S. side of the reserve. The two are not related. Harold Tarbell is the only one of the three chiefs on the council who opposes gambling, and Oakes said his defeat would help solve the crisis. ``We believe they will start listening to the will of the people instead of letting things linger and fester,'' he said. The gambling feud has been simmering since late last July, when the FBI and New York state police raided the casinos and confiscated scores of slot machines. Mohawk traditionalists claim that gambling goes against the Mohawk way of life; gambling supporters say the casinos bring needed revenue and jobs to the reservation.

DOC.HEAD: Cruise Liner Runs Aground _ But the Party Rages On
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with attempts to free ship postponed until Monday, CORRECT name of ship to Regent Star, sted Regency Star; picks up 4th graf, ```The lights ...' SUBS last graf to conform.
DOC.TEXT: A luxury liner with 1,360 people aboard lost power and ran aground Sunday, but instead of triggering panic, it was a chance to ``party hardy a little longer,'' passengers said. Nobody was in danger, the Coast Guard reported, and passengers on the 642-foot Regent Star said they were enjoying free champagne cocktails supplied by the crew. Initial attempts to free the ship with tugboats failed and the Coast Guard said another attempt would have to wait until high tide, about 2 p.m. Monday. The tugs were going to try at high tide after midnight Sunday, but Lt. James Weakley said the Coast Guard felt ``it would be better to try it in daylight'' for safety reasons. The shipping company, Regency Shipping, must pay for the operation, but the Coast Guard will supervise, he said. A small electrical fire in a switchboard apparently caused the power failure around 1 a.m. on what was to be the last day of a seven-day trip from Montego Bay, Jamaica, to Philadelphia. The Regent Star drifted into a sandbar 22 miles north of Cape May in the Delaware Bay separating Delaware and New Jersey, according to Petty Officer John Brazell, a Coast Guard spokesman. ``The lights went out in the disco, everybody was singing `Hot, hot hot,''' Kathleen Hopkins, a reporter at the Elizabeth Daily Journal who was on board, said by phone. Later, they sang Christmas carols and played an improvised version of ``The Newlywed Game.'' ``People started chanting `Drinks, drinks drinks,''' and free mimosas started flowing, Hopkins said. ``Nobody's really scared, everybody is having a good time.'' ``I think it's fun, one big party,'' said Brian Forman, a computer consultant from Philadelphia. ``The party is never going to end.'' ``It just gave us a great opportunity to party hardy a little longer,'' Barbara Sowden of Wilmington, Del., said by phone. ``We don't need a band, we make our own music.'' The Coast Guard directed marine traffic away from the area.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General at Scranton Commencement
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh told graduating students at Scranton University on Sunday that Americans must encourage freedom around the world to allow other nations to copy ``democracy's grand design.'' ``We, both by example and exhortation, have the opportunity, indeed the responsibility, to offer our best hopes for freedom to this awakening world,'' Thornburgh told a crowd of 7,000 at the commencement. ``We must provide maximum exposure to our democratic culture and the traditions of our political philosophy _ so that other nations may emulate democracy's grand design, which is to elevate the dignity of the individual and then respect, absolutely, that individual's rights and liberties. ``We must remind ourselves of the abiding commitment that democracy has made to increase individual rights, to assure due process, and to fine-tune our system so that we maintain that precarious balance between freedom and security,'' Thornburgh said. Thornburgh, who served two terms as Pennsylvania's governor, told the students that every citizen can help change occur. ``I will grant you a healthy skepticism about your ability to right all the world's wrongs, but make sure that what you express is skepticism and not cynicism,'' he said. ``It is within your reach to raise new standards for yourselves and the nation. Grasp this challenge firmly, and do everything you can to move the world ahead.'' The university conferred 919 undergraduate degrees at the ceremony.

DOC.HEAD: Man Kills Wife, Self and Wounds Neighbor in Afternoon Shootout
DOC.TEXT: A man shot and killed his wife after an argument and wounded a neighbor Sunday before killing himself with a 12-gauge shotgun, police said. Dutchess County Sheriff Fred Scoralick said his office was called just before 2 p.m. about the shooting in this upstate New York community. Milton Thorp, 46, shot and killed his wife, Beverly, 51, and seriously wounded a neighbor, Shelley Dingee, 30, Scoralick said. Dingee, who was shot in the right shoulder, was listed in stable condition Sunday night at St. Francis Hospital in Poughkeepsie, hospital officials said. The Thorps apparently had argued and Beverly Thorp went next door to talk to Dingee in her back yard, Scoralick said. Milton Thorp apparently stood in the bed of a pickup truck in his back yard and shot the two women before going in his home and shooting himself, Scoralick said. The Thorps were pronounced dead at the scene.

DOC.HEAD: Yale Students Urged to Build More Just Society
DOC.TEXT: The president of the Children's Defense Fund urged Yale University seniors Sunday to build a more just society, and told them to remember even small efforts count. ``Enough fleas biting strategically can make even the biggest dog uncomfortable,'' said Marian Wright Edelman. Edelman, the first woman chosen by Yale seniors to be their Class Day speaker, told the students they will be graduating Monday into an ``ethically polluted nation'' where the standard for success is too often ``personal greed rather than public good.'' ``I hope America redefines what success means in the 1990s,'' she said. She gave the seniors the same stern advice she said she is passing on to her three children. ``Never just work for money,'' she said. ``Don't confuse wealth and fame for character. Never confuse morality with legality. Don't condone corruption. Don't do just as little as you can to get by.'' Eldeman is a 1963 graduate of Yale Law School and founder of the Washington-based Children's Defense Fund, an advocacy group for children's rights. Class Day at Yale is filled with traditions. As has been the custom since the 1860s, each member of the graduating class was given a long clay pipe and packet of tobacco. Each student was also given a white handkerchief to wave at the conclusion of the singing of ``Bright College Years,'' which ends with the line, ``For God, for Country, and for Yale!'' The Ivy Ode, delivered over the years in languages ranging from Lithuanian to Classical Chinook, was read in Armenian this year while other seniors carried on the nearly 140-year-old tradition of the planting of the Class Ivy.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Says Christianity Must Play Major Role in New Europe
DOC.TEXT: Touring the ancient shrines of this Mediterranean crossroads, Pope John Paul II said Sunday that Christianity must play a central role in the new Europe emerging after the collapse of Communist rule. The concept of a united Europe based on recognition of Christian roots has been a major theme of the pope in recent months, and he raised it again on this island he called ``a marvelous symbiosis of European and Mediterranean culture.'' As evidence of Malta's historic position as a crossroads of civilizations, he pointed to its playing host to the U.S.-Soviet superpower summit in December. John Paul, who returned to Rome on Sunday night at the end of his three-day visit to Malta, said recent changes in Europe show ``the inadequacy and failure of a culture which was not built on the primacy of the spiritual dimension of the human person.'' ``The present challenge facing Europe is to rediscover its own deepest roots. In accepting this challenge, European culture is forcefully called to account for the Christian faith that gave form to its peoples,'' the pope told a group of professors, writers and other cultural figures on Malta. The Vatican says 99 percent of Malta's 350,000 people are Roman Catholics, and John Paul has repeatedly stressed that church values were the island's ``most precious inheritance.'' Maltese marked the first visit ever by a pope as a giant holiday, setting off fireworks and booming cannon salutes wherever John Paul visited. On Sunday, John Paul prayed at St. Paul's Grotto, where Maltese say the apostle was shipwrecked in the year 60 and founded the first Christian community. The Polish-born pope's enthusiasm for the changes in Eastern Europe has been tempered by wariness for what he calls a ``narrow sense of spiritual inspiration'' among peoples. ``Men and women of culture that you are, you know that the restoration of external freedoms is only the first stage, the first step,'' he said Sunday. ``The exercise of freedom must be accompanied by a growth in moral and spiritual maturity.'' Addressing youths in a soccer stadium on Sunday, John Paul called for reconciliation in Maltese society, an apparent reference to bitter quarrels between supporters of the island's two political parties. A papal visit to Malta would have been considered unthinkable under the previous socialist administration, which had sought to reduce the church's dominant role. The Malta trip was the 48th foreign tour of John Paul's papacy. His next scheduled trip is to Africa in September.

DOC.HEAD: `Pioneer,' an Amiable Avante-Garde Play at Spoleto
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs version planned.
DOC.TEXT: The advance word about ``Pioneer'' was that the play was full of profanity and that it attacked the images of famed explorers, suggesting base motives rather than heroism. But ``Pioneer,'' which premiered Saturday at the Spoleto Festival, is more amiable than that. And, surprisingly for an avant-garde play with music and performance art, it's easy to follow. ``Pioneer'' was brought to the regional arts festival by the Paul Dresher Ensemble, based in San Francisco. At the second of four performances Sunday afternoon, perhaps the worst that could be said is that it would have more impact if it lasted an hour instead of an hour and a half. ``Pioneer'' is rather fun, with pulleys enabling lots of stage effects, such as the stacking of five sofas so an actor could scale them like a mountain. The story is mostly about Junior, son of a minor explorer, lost five miles into the forzen north. Junior dies and has his body frozen. Rinde Eckert gets one of the arias dotted through the music, singing, ``100 years from now I'll still be 52.'' Jo Harvey Allen, his widow, has the most talking. Wearing a short black slip, she has the first of the few speeches vulgarity, when she describes the kind of man Junior expected her to take home before he was even cold. Junior was a history buff, and we get ``Cortes Explains Religion to the Natives,'' with John Duykers singing in Spanish and ``explaining'' that the Pope is boss and the natives must do everything he says. There's also an amusing scene in which Adm. Robert Peary is mostly concerned with how he will look in pictures of his travels. Neither he nor the photographer has brought a flag to the North Pole. That's about it for debunking explorers. The widow has a hard time, too depressed to get out of bed. Finally she picks up Duykers, who has several arias and plays several characters. He tears up the floorboards of her house, looking for whatever treasure Junior hid, and leaving the worst mess we've ever seen at a final curtain. ``Pioneer'' has a happy ending, with the widow getting in a car and driving off to resume living. The Spoleto Festival U.S.A. began Friday night with a concert celebrating the festival's survival of last fall's Hurricane Hugo. The Gaillard Auditorium, site of the concert, and Garden Theater, which houses ``Pioneer,'' were the most badly damaged of the festival's 11 performance sites. Both have been refurbished. Leonard Bernstein was ill and canceled his engagement to conduct the opening concert. The highlight of the performances arranged to take his place was Midori, the 18-year-old violinist. With her came Julius Rudel, who'd conducted her in the Bruch ``Scottish Fantasy'' before. Mezzo-soprano Tatiana Troyanos, more dramatic in concert than opera, also arrived on short notice.

DOC.HEAD: Bob, Dolores Hope Receive Honorary Degrees at Commencement
DOC.TEXT: Commencement at the University of San Diego doubtless would have been a solemn occasion Sunday, if not for the class cutup. ``I love commencement. I love the happy, ecstatic, joyous faces _ but enough about the teachers,'' comedian Bob Hope told about 9,000 people attending the ceremony. ``The parents also look so happy,'' he said. ``This is the last payment that they'll have to make on their children.'' Hope, 86, and his wife, Dolores, were presented with honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degrees amidst wild cheers and applause. Before receiving their degrees, the Hopes were lauded by university officials for their humanitarian and philanthropic endeavors. Hope then took center stage. The audience roared and tittered at his trademark one-liners. ``I'm now a doctor, at last I can get on the golf course on Wednesdays,'' he said. Hope's acceptance speech took on a serious tone as he told the more than 700 students receiving degrees that their ``real education is about to begin.'' ``You've gotten the last grades you'll ever get in geometry, history and English Lit,'' Hope said. ``From now on, you'll be attending a far bigger and more important classroom, where your grades will determine how far you will go in devotion, compassion and self-respect. That will be the important curriculum from now on. ``Cicero said, `A room without books is like a body without a soul,''' Hope said. ``I'll never forget when he told me that,'' the comedian added. Dolores Hope, who was celebrating her 81st birthday Sunday, also drew chuckles from the crowd. She thanked the university for honoring her and for ``having Bob Hope as an opening act.''

DOC.HEAD: Performers Denied Visas to Stage Tiananmen Memorial in U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Seven members of a Hong Kong theater troupe have been denied visas to enter the United States to stage a production marking the Tiananmen Square massacre. The seven are stranded in England, where they recently completed five performances, according to Eleanor Yung, executive director of the Asian American Art Center, which is sponsoring the New York performance. The piece, called ``Deep Structure,'' was scheduled for June 2 at the Borough of Manhattan Community College in Manhattan. A pro-Democracy movement in the People's Republic of China was crushed last June 4 when hundreds of demonstrators were killed in Beijing's Tiananmen Square by government troops. Four actors from the Zuni Icosohedron troupe were granted visas, and have been in New York since Thursday. The rest were denied visas by the U.S. Embassy in England, ``The reason they are giving for the denial is they are afraid all the members would not return to Hong Kong and would stay in United States,'' said Ms. Yung. All 11 performers were given clearance about a month ago by the Immigration and Naturalization Service to work temporarily in the United States, Yung said. Yung had also arranged radio and television interviews for the performers, as well as some sightseeing, and had scheduled them to leave June 21. ``My feeling is it's a very sensitive issue with the Tiananmen Square memorial,'' she said. She noted that President Bush last week extended China's most-favored nation trading status over the objections of critics who said China should be punished for suppressing human rights. Yung said Bush ``seems to be very cautious in terms of how to deal with this democracy issue. For us to have a memorial performance commemorating Tiananmen is contrary to their agenda.'' A spokeswoman for the U.S. Department of State, Anita Stockman, referred all questions about the visa denial to the U.S. Embassy in London. Officials there could not immediately be reached for comment. The theater company, whose name refers to an American Indian tribe and a 25-sided geometric shape, was founded in 1982 in Hong Kong, where they performed ``Deep Structure'' earlier this year.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Crashes in Missouri, Killing Company President
DOC.TEXT: A single-engine plane that ``came out of the clouds without its wings'' crashed Sunday in woods in southeast Missouri, killing a company president and his wife, officials said. The victims were identified as Frank M. Adams, president and chief operating officer of Morrison Knudsen Corp., and Novella C. Adams, both 64, of Boise, Idaho. Adams had filed a flight plan under which the plane was to fly from Tennessee to Colorado on Sunday and on to Boise on Monday, officials said. Witnesses reported the crash about four miles northwest of Naylor around 11:45 a.m., said state Highway Patrol Sgt. J.W. Burford. ``They heard a loud noise and saw a plane come out of the clouds without its wings,'' Burford said. The victims were declared dead at the scene. The wings of the Piper PA-46 were found about 300 yards south of the plane's fuselage, the trooper said. There were no storms in the area, but there was a heavy overcast. Authorities said there was no immediate indication of why the plane's wings came off, but speculated that the aircraft may have gone into a steep dive for some reason and Adams' efforts to pull it out put too much strain on the wings. The Federal Aviation Administration, Highway Patrol and Ripley County Sheriff's Office were investigating the crash, Burford said. Morrison Knudsen is an international engineering and construction company with yearly revenues of about $2 billion. It has built most of Anheuser-Busch's breweries. Adams, a Naval Academy graduate and former submarine commander, retired as president of Allied Signal Corp. in February 1988. He came out of retirement to go to work for Morrison Knudsen seven months later.

DOC.HEAD: Mulroney Meets with Premiers, Quebec Crisis Continues
DOC.TEXT: Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney ended a series of inconclusive talks Sunday aimed at persuading provincial premiers to accept an accord recognizing French-speaking Quebec as a ``distinct society.'' The refusal of three provinces to support the agreement has thrown the federal government into a crisis and provoked new fears of succession efforts by Quebec. Emerging from one of the meetings, Newfoundland Premier Clyde Wells said: ``The differences are substantial and serious and resolution will not be easy.'' Mulroney commented: ``Obviously, we have serious problems.'' Mulroney is hoping to salvage what is known as the Meech Lake agreement before its June 23 deadline. Quebec refused to sign Canada's 1982 constitution. To win its support, Mulroney and all 10 premiers signed a five-point amendment at Meech Lake, near Ottawa, in 1987, and set a three-year deadline for ratification by the provincial legislatures. But the governments changed in three provinces _ Newfoundland, Manitoba and New Brunswick _ and the new premiers have refused to back the amendment. The Meech Lake accord would define Quebec as a ``distinct society'' from the rest of Canada as a way to protect its French language and culture.

DOC.HEAD: Oklahomans Recover from Twisters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `Franci' in 7th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Residents dug through debris Sunday to find belongings strewn by a series of tornadoes, including five pickup trucks that were flung a quarter of a mile, officials said. The tornadoes destroyed three houses and severely damaged two others late Saturday in this southwestern Oklahoma community, police said. There were no reports of injuries. ``We found a little more debris today,'' Hinton police dispatcher Brent Tucker said Sunday. ``My assistant chief said he stood on a hill outside the city last night and saw what looked like a half-mile path of total destruction.'' There were reports of as many as three funnel clouds. The five pickup trucks were blown about a quarter-mile from their parking spots during the storm, six cattle disappeared and five horses were killed, Tucker said. ``There was a John Deere tractor with a disc (plow) on it that was in the storm,'' Tucker said. ``They found the disc but are still looking for the tractor.'' Six families were left homeless, said Oklahoma County Red Cross spokesman Franci Hart. Police dispatcher Mike Michaelis in Binger about 10 miles to the south said a tornado touched down outside city limits and damaged a house and barn. The National Weather Service said the twister was reported about five miles west of Binger at 8:52 p.m., moving to the east. Another twister was reported two miles east of the city. The nearby town of Gracemont was hit by baseball-sized hail that knocked holes in the roof of the fire station, said city firefighter Ray Watts. He said he was unaware of any reports of other damage or injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Two Barges Break Loose, One Caught
DOC.TEXT: Two barges broke loose from their moorings Sunday, prompting police to close a bridge over the Monongahela River to keep the runaway vessels from striking support piers. The barges, which authorities said were moored in Braddock at the Rochez Brothers construction supply company, drifted five miles down the river after breaking free at 2 p.m. Police in five riverside cities, including Pittsburgh, watched as the barges spun downstream, rebounding off the shore at times. One of the barges beached on a sandbar above Homestead. The other passed under the closed High Level Bridge in Homestead without incident. The barge was still stuck on the sandbar late Sunday; the other was rounded up by a towboat and taken back to the company, officials said. A Coast Guard spokesman said the incident was under investigation. The barges broke free during high-water conditions on Pittsburgh's three major rivers.

DOC.HEAD: High Winds Topple Festival Stage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf, `The storms ...,' with two grafs to ADD wind speeds; picks up last graf.
DOC.TEXT: Strong thunderstorm winds ripped down a stage at a festival Sunday, injuring 27 people, police said. Several thousand people at the Baton Rouge Fest for All were watching a warm-up band and waiting for a performance by the Temptations when the accident occurred around 5:30 p.m., said Sgt. Carl Thompson. ``The stage was covered with a canopy and there were speaker towers on either side,'' Thompson said. ``The wind came up and collapsed the towers.'' Two people were hospitalized with facial lacerations and broken bones, said paramedic Mark Olson. Twenty-five others were treated for minor injuries and released. ``None of the band members were hurt,'' Olson said. `It was mostly the people in the front of the stage, hurt by the speakers tumbling down.'' The two people most seriously injured were removed from beneath the collapsed stage, Olson said. He estimated the crowd at 5,000. The stage platform, which was made of scaffolding, was about two stories high, Olson said. The speaker units, each about 5 feet tall, were stacked on separate 7-foot-high scaffoldings on either side of the stage. The annual music and arts festival is held for two weekends on streets throughout the downtown area of Louisiana's capital city. The stage which collapsed was located in the parking lot of the Baton Rouge Centroplex, which is part of the city government building complex. The Temptations show was to have been the festival finale. Officials canceled the show. The storms wreaked havoc through much of the state Sunday evening, knocking down trees and cutting power to thousands. Winds gusted to 47 mph in Baton Rouge and 78 mph in the New Orleans area. There were several reports of tornadoes, but none of the sightings was immediately confirmed. About 25,000 people in New Orleans were without electricity for at least part of the evening, said Mike Sanders of New Orleans Public Service Inc. Power outages were also reported in central Louisiana.

DOC.HEAD: Keystone Camera Accuses Kodak of Abandoning U.S. Camera Industry
DOC.TEXT: Keystone Camera Corp. has charged that industry giant Eastman Kodak Co. ``has abandoned'' the U.S. camera industry by relying on imports of foreign-made cameras. Keystone is seeking higher tariffs on all imports of hand-held 35mm cameras, except single lens reflex models, and on fixed-focus hand-held 110 cameras. Kodak opposes to the proposed hike in tariffs. ``We have not, of course, abandoned the U.S. camera market. We are still a domestic producer of cameras,'' said Paul Allen, a spokesman at Kodak's Rochester, N.Y., headquarters. Allen said Keystone's accusations were ``flawed from a factual viewpoint.'' He said Kodak would respond in papers to be filed with the U.S. International Trade Commission next week. In March, Keystone asked the commission to restrict imports for five years, saying a ``flood'' of imports threatens its competitive ability. Keystone describes itself as the sole remaining American manufacturer of conventional 35-millimeter and 110 cameras and has said 500 jobs at its Clifton base are at stake if tariffs aren't raised. Last week, Kodak said they opposed Keystone's petition because ``import restrictions would reduce the popularity of photography, putting at risk thousands of jobs for people who work in all elements of the photographic industry.'' Keystone executive Steve Ehrlich said Friday that Kodak is ``a non-player in the camera industry. Their last two efforts show that, with the disc and the instant.'' Ehrlich acknowledged that Keystone went to Kodak in January and offered to manufacture domestically-made cameras to be marketed under the Kodak name. Ehrlich said the higher tariffs would lead to higher prices for Kodak cameras while Keystone, with 1989 sales of $42 million, would be able to reduce its prices because it could produce more cameras. Kodak, the world's largest photography company, said it had sales of $18.4 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Soviet Analysts Grow Pessimistic For Gorbachev
With AM-Soviet Reforms, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Leading U.S. analysts have offered some of their most pessimistic assessments yet of Mikhail Gorbachev's future in the wake of an economic reform proposal most experts consider a disaster. ``(Gorbachev's) destiny is linked to this price reform,'' said Judy Shelton, a Stanford University economist who has written a critical book about the Soviet economy. Calling the proposed tripling of basic food prices untenable, Shelton predicted: ``I think the day the bread price hike takes effect, he'll be out.'' Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov announced plans last week for a public referendum on an economic plan that would raise prices of most products by next year, including a tripling of bread prices by Jan. 1. U.S. experts predicted spreading strikes and devastating runs on stores and hoarding in anticipation of price hikes. ``I would be prepared to say that this moves him one step closer'' to falling from power, said Harvard University historian Marshall Goldman. The proposed five-year plan is a compromise between the decades-old centrally planned economy _ under which Moscow set virtually all prices and wages _ and radical plans for a Polish-style ``shock-therapy'' to shift to a market economy over two years. Soviet lawmakers are divided about the cures for numerous economic ills. Wages are soaring in the double digits while industrial production has dropped significantly. The country has a huge budget deficit, shortages are chronic and consumers wait in long, demoralizing lines to buy the few goods available. Soviet officials describe the proposed new system as a regulated market, because wage and price controls would be lifted gradually, and not all state businesses would be sold. Although the plan would allow many Soviet enterprises and properties to be bought and sold, as well as go bankrupt, Western experts said it wasn't radical enough to solve the country's festering problems. ``Getting halfway there may be worse than never even starting,'' said Ed Hewitt, a Soviet analyst at the Brookings Institute, a Washington think tank. Soviet polls have indicated that about half of Soviet citizens would support a free market system. But it was unclear whether they would vote for skyrocking prices and unprecedented unemployment based on promises of better times by a government that, by its own admission, lacks solid popular support. ``He's lost credibility. His situation has deteriorated so much,'' Goldman said in a telephone interview. ``The methods that he should have used _ markets, family farming, joint ventures _ have gotten off to such a bad start.'' Hewitt said he was less worried about Gorbachev's personal position than about his ability to govern after the referendum, for which no date has been set. ``The one mistake that we've made over the last few years is that we've underestimated him,'' Hewitt said. ``But I'm sure that the economic reform package will not work. If they don't pull it back and do something more serious, they're going to do more damage than from five years of wandering in the wilderness.'' Shelton said the price hikes were intended to raise money to eliminate the Soviet budget deficit, estimated at anywhere between $40 billion and $165 billion. ``This is not a market plan. Their prices always have been fixed. Now they will just be fixed at the market rate,'' she said. Shelton said Gorbachev was caught between the need to convert quickly to a market system and a fear of popular unrest over high unemployment and prices that would result. He chose a middle route of retaining control of higher prices. Hewitt said the referendum decision reflected the government's own lack of credibility. ``The government and whole leadership are acutely aware they are not elected, so they decided to have elected policies,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Tobacco Analysts Don't Expect Run On Stocks With Harvard's Sales
DOC.TEXT: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) _ A move by two universities to divest tobacco stocks shouldn't trigger a barrage of sell orders, analysts say, but it hasn't helped the industry's image. ``It is only an egghead institution that would do it,'' John C. Mazwell, an analyst at Wheat First Butcher & Singer in Richmond, Va., said of the recent divestment decisions by Harvard University and the City University of New York. ``It makes absolutely no sense. This is a legal product,'' he said. Still, the divestiture could give momentum to the anti-smoking movement and to efforts to restrict tobacco sales in the United States, analysts say. On Thursday, Louis W. Sullivan, the secretary of health and human services, called on state and local governments to curb cigarette sales to minors by banning cigarette-vending machines. Maxwell said he doubted such a ban would have an impact on the tobacco industry because machines account for only about three percent of sales. But Calvert Crary, an analyst with Martin Simpson & Co., said the divestitures could change public thinking about the tobacco industry. ``The companies' ability to exist has to do with the public's and regulators' perception,'' he told the Winston-Salem Journal. ``As long as the public agrees that tobacco is OK, that's the environment it needs to survive and thrive in.'' Domestic tobacco sales have been declining gradually, Crary said. ``With a sudden shift in regulator and consumer perception on the product and tightened regulatory restrictions, you could accelerate that trend,'' he said. Harvard began selling its tobacco holdings last year. The City University of New York announced recently that it would sell all of its stock in companies that make tobacco products. Derek Bok, Harvard's president, wrote in a letter to students May 18 that the university divested because of the health risks of smoking and the aggressive marketing tactics by the industry to sell cigarettes to teen-agers. Diana K. Temple, an analyst for Salomon Bros., said, ``I don't see a wholesale movement right now away from tobacco.'' She said religious and some other groups have refused to invest in tobacco for years. Most investors, she said, were more concerned about the potential impact of a batch of lawsuits against tobacco companies in recent years that have tried to hold the companies liable for smokers who have died of lung cancer. Most institutional investors, said Emanuel Goldman of Paine Webber, are more interested in improving the value of investments than with the morality of a company. ``My point is the objective of money managers is to maximize their return, and if you leave out the tobacco stock, you'll be limiting yourself,'' he said.
